content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												A fantastic citybuilder, my favourite since SimCity 4.Since the most likely points of comparison here are SimCity 2015 and Cities XL, I'll break it down into quick points:Compared to SimCity 2015:-Game's fully offline. The only online aspect is the integration with Steam Workshop.-Deep modding. Game include's both a map editor and an asset editor. Workshop is already bursting at the seams with stuff.-Giantic room for constructing cities. You start with a single 2x2 km square, and you can eventually purchase 8 more squares. There's already mods allowing to purchase all 25 squares a map has (that's 100 sq km).-Cims (Skylines' version of Sims) are fully simulated and actually make sense.-Traffic simulation is incredibly deep (though there's still some issues with cars accumulating in a single lane sometimes).-No building upgrade.-Specialization is not as deep as in SimCity, but the District system allows you to essentially create individual cities within the same map, with their own laws, taxes, and industrial focuses.-Several info overlays are almost copied from SimCity, even in their presentation.-Skylines is less colourful than SimCity, but also a bit more realistic.-Music isn't bad in Skylines, but SimCity's better.Compared to Cities XL-Map are just a little bit smaller (Cities XL has 110 sq km, Skylines has 100 sq km with mods, 36 sq km without).-Zoning is much, more comfortable, particularly with curved roads.-No lag (although large cities can be taxing depending on your computer). Brisk road building even for huge tracks.-Graphics are somewhat similar.-Interface is far more user-friendly.-Traffic simulation is orders of magnitude more interesting.-Road variety is more or less the same (just in terms of types. Skylines' free-form roadbuilding allows for pretty much unlimited road-building methods).-So far, I've encountered not a single memory leak or similarly wrecking bug.Overall, the game is great. It is true it is in some aspects less deep than SimCity 4 and it does have some usability nuances (such as zoning not always looking exactly the way you want, though this is the price we pay for free-form orientation, I suppose), but it does so much stuff so great that you quickly let that pass. Traffic itself is so well done that it becomes a game unto itself (which is no wonder, considering the game was developed by the same people behind Cities in Motion).Modding support is also excellent. Though the base game comes with a somewhat limited variety of buildings, ten minutes in the Workshop will land you with several dozen new structures that will seamless integrate into your cities, and new stuff is being made faster than we can check it.Some of the missing stuff, such as tunnels, is already being considered as free DLCs in the near future.10/10 game. This is both the citibuilder we wanted and the citibuilder we deserved.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Just a short review here: Cities Skylines is a really nice game. It clearly takes its inspiration from both classic Sim City and the recent Sim City 2013, however, it ends up being something really quite special. The simulation is really robust. I've yet to find any major problems and/or bugs. My cities have had issues but they've all been the result of my poor planning, and with a little thought and re-working I have managed to fix them and learn from my mistakes in a way that is very satisfying. The depth of simulation vs. abstraction is also great. Some things, such as wind-drection and night/day cycles are missing but they don't have any noticable impact on the gameplay once you are involved.I think that the lack of need for a tutorial speaks volumes too. The game just makes sense. You can bring your real-life knowledge of how towns and cities are set up here along with a healthy dose of common sense and you will succeed. The result is the feeling that you really are creating and overseeing a living community rather than simply gaming a system which is fantastic.Over all, I really recommend this game to anyone that has even a passing interest in city building games. Its by far the best option on the market now, and its going to take something pretty special to beat it any time soon.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												If you're a fan of cities simulator, you've just found the perfect game for you, buddy. Congratulations.This game managed to overcome Sim City 2000 and Sim City 4 combined, two of my favourite city manager simulators ever. In Cities: Skylines you'll start building your city from just an intersection coming out of a highway in the middle of nowhere, manage your budget, expand, make some decisions (not enough cash, do I build a fire station or a hospital?), expand even more, watch as your small poor village in the middle of nowhere becomes a gigantic metropolis that people from all around the world come to visit.All in all, Cities: Skylines managed to be everything SimCity's reboot failed to be. The only con I have with this game is that it somehow lacks introduction, there are small tips here and there, but the complicated parts you have to discover pretty much by yourself (or search for tutorials on Youtube, lol).Now excuse me while I lose some more hours of sleep expanding my city. ):

number of helpful: 86 of 162 people (53%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												It really was a fun game, but it quickely devolved in to a shallow, unchallenging experience.Once you learn the tricks on how to organize your city it becomes pretty easy. The basic core is you have to manage the demands of your city while building new infrustructure. Sounds fun, except it really comes down to 3 demands: Housing, Industry, and Commercial. If the demand for housing goes up? Build a road and zone it for houses. How about Industry and Commercial? Do the same thing.Sure, there are other things like resource management where you actually have to have the power, water/sewage, and other civil services. But a few hours in to my game I guess I found a sweet spot between growth and taxes because my cash flow exploded in to the millions before I even realized it happened. I could put hospitals and police on every street corner.My city had become somewhat of a paradise, and it felt too easy.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
 Cities:Skylines by Colossal Order A beutiful and addicting game that I probably will spend hours on end playing. If you like games like Civ 5 or Democracy 3, you will probably love this as well! So here are the pro's and cons: Good: - No EA (meaning no microtransactions. Oops, looks like you have to pay £0,99 to read on!)- Graphics- Simulation- Gameplay- Map editor- European maps- The ablility to rename EVERY single car and house, and it stays that way. You can also rename dogs, so I did. I called it dogmeat (Fallout-fans, please, contain your örgasms. I had to write örgasm for Steam to not censor it. And it sounds pretty damn funny.)-And now, contrary to popular beliefs; the Chirper (it isn't that bad if you click the "don't open the messages automatically. It can actually help you a lot. Also, it's kinda cute).- The feeling that it's alive- Almost everything else The Meh - Hot-dog trucks - Building variation isn't too great.- Not that many monuments... The Bad - Map editor water tool. Uncontrollable and just spreads everywere. Also no undo button for this (10/10 would have to make a new map 3 times).- The #use of #haschtags in #all the #tweets. @developers, please #reduce the amount of #haschtags thank #you #yoloswag.- No special districts for office zones (marketing, software, entrepreneurship etc.)- No actual Hadron colliders.- You not having it in your Steam libraryMy score  10/10 My necessary silly review quote: I renamed a guys car to "The Hippie Van" and watched his house burn down, probably because I doused his kitchen in gasoline. I then threw the remains in the landfill. Then I played Cities Skylines and it was fun.  (EDIT) This game has made me realise why the world looks like it does today. I neglected worries about polution, noise and health, focused only on making the city as big as possible. When I realised I became legitimately scared. No other game has made me get such a enlightenment, it truly terrifies me. GG world.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Been looking forward to this games release for a while and after having the chance to play it for a while, i am -generaly- satisfied. I am happy to reccomend this game, as it goes back to the roots of proper city building we know from the early days of sim city and beyond. However! There are a few issues, which i am willing to pinn to the fact it's fresh out, though a few of those really should have been adressed prior to release.- No autosave! > Really? Game like this? With no autosave? I've already lost hours of gameplay because of game crashes.- Emergency services being ignored by other traffic reguardless of road type. > What do they have them sirens for then, if they stop at traffic lights anyway? Enough said.- No terrain mod tools available in game. > I would have expected these to be in, other then the map mod tool, they should be available while playing, payed for, certainly, but you should be able to buy some dirt and shove it along the shoreline to make a proper dam, or flatten that big mountain in the middle of your city.- Inability to modify the base maps. > if we can't have tools in game, why can't we open the default maps in the terrain modifier?- Water. > Don't get me wrong, love the water physics, though it does seem a little sluggish in places and crazy in others, bit hard to predict at times.These are the few issues i've noticed thus far in my 10 hours of gameplay, more might come up, but overall i am happy, just really, really missing the autosave and really really baffled by the emergency services.Rock on Paradox!

Posted: March 12, 2015
 Yes it is the game you have waited for! I’ve watched Streamers for around twenty hours before picking this game up and after sinking a few hours into Cities: Skylines I can say this is a wonderful realisation of how a city builder can be done.The attention to detail is fantastic from its easy and slick UI to the ability to stalk and name anyone you choose. They have made the game wonderfully accessible and deceptively deep if you love the micromanagement side. I won’t list what this game does right and what others fail to do as others already have, all I will say is this game is well worth your time. Side note It amazes me how a small team of six (I believe fourteen now) can make this wonderful gem of a game that will no doubt become the next pillar for city builders meanwhile at EA and Maxis they mess up so badly. Regardless of the pedigree, cash and talent they had backing it. Fantastic job Colossal Order and more power to you.

content:
Posted: March 16
												There’s a lot of tools and a lot to learn. Across the bottom of the screen is a toolbar that contains all the stuff you need to create your city. Initially there is only a limited selection for you to play with. As your population grows more tools become available and the pacing is just perfect.Features like global policies that can reduce power consumption or increase fire safety are introduced at a rate that never feels like a bombardment. The same goes for buildings and services. Rather than a sit down and read endless pop-ups style tutorial features are gradually introduced so that only small explanations are needed at each stage. It really lets you get hooked even during those often tedious early learning stages. Another reason Skylines is so fun straight from the start is that each and every tool you use is so effortless.There’s a zone system used that is very similar to everyone’s favourite Sim City game. But again the tools are there for you to make your life easy. Streets come ready equipped with grids attached that you can either paint one square at a time, use a paint brush tool or even a fill tool to create entire blocks easily. Then waiting just a little time everything comes to life as buildings are erected and citizens go about their daily lives.All this simplicity isn’t to imply that Skylines isn’t complex. Underneath the user friendly interface there are a set of menus and tables that reveal some of the numbers that lie beneath. Finances, happiness, healthcare, education, crime and transport are all detailed enough to make Skylines worthy of any city building fan.The only thing that some may not like is the slightly sandbox style, especially later in the game. Once the learning curve and introduction of tools is done with there are very little objectives to give you direction. THE GOOD- Cities offer room for expansion- Beautifully detailed miniature village style looks- introduction and learning curve- Great tool designedTHE BAD- Lack of objectivesDISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												I definitely recommend this game.  I’m a long time Simcity fan going back to the middle school's computer lab playing Sim City 2000 in the year 1999 on a bright and beautiful iMac.  I even remember the teacher showing kids how to play the game.  What better way to teach kids the value of well funded schools?This game exists mostly because under the ownership of EA the Simcity series has really faltered.  Major technical issues and limitations and lost opportunities and hurt the series.This game is easy, much easier than any Simcity game I’ve played.  Some of it is easier because things just work better, like the water pipe systems.  The economics are just a lot easier.  I actually think this is more realistic.  I live in California, and here government funding isn’t really an issue, the issue is that throwing money at problems doesn't really help a lot.  Traffic isn’t an issue of money, it's an issue of what to do.  Same goes for crime, education, and especially water, or even pollution.  City skylines emulates this, money isn’t a big problem, but planning and management is the heart of the challenge.  ProsGreat aesthetics.  Night time is absolutely beautiful. The city looks great.So many options as far as roads, zoning, utilities, really fun variety.I like the easy economics which let you just focus on city building.Steam workshop and lots of mods.The size of the maps is amazing.  As your city grows you will unlock more and more land, faster than you could fill it.  It really puts Simcity franchise to shame.ConsIt's going to push your system a little bit, but luckily frame rate isn't super important in this genre.The mass transit bus/train stop system with routes feels a little clunky and odd to me.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This game started off awsome, complete  with the whole new car smell - so to speak. I was sooo happy that it felt like simcity 4 but with a fully 3d integrated world and a fully rotational camera. Then as I continued to play I became overwhelmingly unimpressed with how "unfinished" the game was.The game has very limited "Parks & Rec." places to plop down and make people feel happy about where they live. You also cant "Free place" parks and a lot of buildings either as they are required to snap to a road... So if you find yourself in the alto familiar (atleast for me) situation where as your city grows some areas just dont fully integrate and create pockets of unbildable area, and so you decide you want to make a park or "Pretty" area in that awkward area - well you cant. You have to have a road running in there as you cant just make it a spruced up area... even if you dont care that it people cant useit because you just want the area to look better to you... you still cant do it without a road. The game also has limited utilities and services available and instead relies on the modding community to make up the difference in how little is actually available for what you pay for the game... If you can pick this game up for under $10 bucks its worth a buy to tinker with - Anything above that and you will likely be disapointed in this game due to how little you are getting for what you pay for. You will then have to turn to the modding commnity to get key portions of the game patched over with much needed features that should have been included.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												I've just started, but since this just came out I want to help the guys and girls still on the fence.   It reminds me Sim City 4, but with modern improvements! It is easy to play, and the game explains the core concepts as you go.  This is the city builder that we have been waiting for. Click Add to cart, now.  Before I describe the game, I have had absolutely no choppiness and I have the game maxed out.  If you have a quality PC you should have no issues running this game.You have 9 different maps to choose from.  There is no random map option, but there is an editor included that you can create your own maps or download maps from other players. So, you will always have new maps to play on.The game has a few interesting subsystems that work together.  The more educated your citizens are, the less trash they will produce.  Poorer the neighborhood will lead to more crime.  You have to keep your pollution levels down or you could risk tainting the drinking water of your citizens.There are multiple road options to allow you to truly customize the shape and direction of your town.Do you want to build a eco friendly paradise or do you want to build the biggest city that you can? The game gives you the tools for you to decide. Also, with the editors available there should be plenty of options coming from other players.For the old timers who remember Sim City on the SNES (I know it was PC first, but back then a SNES was a few hundred dollars and PC's were $2,000 easy) for everytime you reach a population milestone you level up your ability to add items to your city.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2016
A prime example of the benefits of PC gamingCities: Skylines is what happens when you develop a game without consoles in mind. ✓ Fun and addictingHear me out: I've always avoided city building games like the plague because I thought they weren't my cup of tea. The free weekend came along and I thought "why not?"... look at my hours now.✓ 100% moddableSpecific buildings of all types, colors and flavors, intersections, maps, different lighting settings, gameplay-altering mods... just about anything can be found in the workshop. Be warned though: using mods disables achievements.✓ Fair learning curveYou might think a game like this is too complicated, but the truth is... it's not. Cities: Skylines is as complicated as you make it. Sure, if you're a beginner (like me), your first cities will fail, but that's exactly what makes this game so replayable: you learn by failing, and it's fun as hell.✓ Endless possibilities and replayabilityRural town? Metropolis? European capital? Futuristic city? A replica of your town? The only limit is your imagination[gfycat.com]✗ No season passAs of now, they've released two expansions: After Dark and Snowfall. They'll release more, and that's good, but there's no way to buy a game+expansions pack, which means that no one knows the pricetag for the ultimate experience, and you might end up spending hundreds of euros in the game if they keep releasing expansions. You might think "how is that a problem? If they release more content, I'll happily pay". Well, look at Train Simulator. Would you pay 4,000€ for the full experience? I'm not saying Paradox will take the same route, but they could, and you should be wary.VerdictCities: Skylines has quickly turned into one of my favorite games. I've always liked scale models[www.archivisionmodels.com]. This game is like having your own, but alive. I thoroughly recommend it.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I LOVE this game. It's everything Simcity looked like it should have been. The entire city you manage is persistant and constantly evolving, meaning- people live, work, and commute to the same places in the same vehicle every day (you can click on cars and see who owns them!). and even eventually have familes and die. The game can be as simple, or as complex as you want, with the ability to create districts which allow you to set individual laws and regulations, turning industrial zones into farming areas with low taxes, residential into luxury apartments with high taxes, or specialized industy areas to gather resources like oil, coal, and wood (yes, forestry is a thing in this). Not to mention, EVERYTHING is renamable; Districts, people, and buildings.And buildings. You can't forget about the fact that you can MAKE and SHARE buildings, parks, and even maps with powerful, but easy to use in game asset editors. Its easy to go to the workshop, grab some maps, buildings, or lots you like and add them to your game!Placement of buildings is also important. A lot of buildings will create polution- but not just the regular type you would expect like smog and soil polution- many buildings will also create noise polution, and make people living near them very upset.It's like they took all the best features from the -old- simcity games (water pipes and power lines YAY!), re-engineered them, put their own twist on some things, and made a beautiful game out of it. Incredibly happy with this purchase, especially considering the wonderfully reasonable price. WHY ARE YOU STILL READING THIS!? BUY IT. :D

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												A great city-builder, this game takes all the best city-building game mechanics and puts them together in a well-balanced package.  The UI is a little obtuse in some areas, and not all of the important information is clearly conveyed, but you can get used to it.  Traffic is a big part of the game, and the quality of your road layouts will make or break your city.  Fortunately, the AI is very adept at pathfinding through your streets, and problem locations can easily identified by the traffic jams.  The economy is very easy and forgiving, so you can mostly just focus the fun part of designing and not have to worry much about micromanaging your economy.  Everything SimCity (2015) did wrong, this game did right.

												The citybuilder that fans have been clamoring for since Simcity 2013 proved to be such a disaster. Simple as that. No always-online requirement, no tiny city plots with vast tracts of empty land in between, no desync between cities and no 'this sim wakes up in this house, but goes to whatever empty house is closest to work when his day is done'. This game, it's developer and its publisher takes gamers and their wishes seriously. You want a game that's challenging, fun to play, beautiful to look at and has amazing replay value? Get Cities: Skylines. Period.Maxis is dead. All hail Colossal Order and Paradox Interactive!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												Finally, a perfect blend of two classic genres: urban planning and traffic management. Especially traffic management. Although the game is meant to be a successor to Simcity 4 and an epic "take that" at Simcity 5, it's more of an expansion pack for Cities in Motion 2 since you'll be spending most of your time building costly road layouts and alleviating impossibly-complex traffic grimlocks originating from said road layouts. Thankfully this time you have a proper user-friendly GUI and grid/non-grid transition system to assist you when placing and aligning splines according to your OCD level. Be sure to always focus on transit-oriented development rather than classic suburban sprawl as this game is almost completely Northwest Euro-centric in nature.Compared to SC4 though, many vital elements are either oversimplified or nonexistent; whilst new concepts such as sewage disposal are shoved up your♥♥♥♥♥without regard to any learning curve, and normally mundane tasks become so overpowered such that it's an instant game-over if your rubbish trucks are too slow. (No, seriously.) Starting a new town, however, is considerably less tedious as there are in-built milestones to restrict asset requirements to your population growth level. But ultimately, this game is set in the present day, when your cims expect everything from power to water and even Internet services from the moment you zone your first residential area and have nearly zero tolerance or grace period for any unfortunate events; so treat all your peepur like stereotypical teenage white girls at all times or it's express bankruptcy for you. Whether take this as a challenge or setback, your mileage may vary. Interesting new features like fluid mechanics and restricted aviation pathways also help to determine your final city layout, reducing the monotony of the mid-game era.Personally, I feel that Colossal Order have definitely learnt from most of their mistakes committed in CIM2; whether or not Paradox published games' infamous DLC-spam policy also applies to this release is yet to be confirmed. Many of the other "overwhelmingly positive" reviews seem to be rants from starved city-building fanboys and SC5 haters who long-awaited a player-friendly magnum opus of the genre, praising CSL for the messianic role it plays in the wake of SC5's epic failure with little thought about the potential shortcomings of this hastily-released masterpiece. Even though flaws in the Unity Engine's ability to cope with the game design remain evident, it's clear why this game broke 1,000,000 purchases in about the time it took for Gangnam Style views to hit 100 times that number. And yes, you can mod that in-game too, for free.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												95 hours of gameplay and I have only one city that is thriving. I almost reached to 100k people yet there is alot more to do. The achievement system, in my opinion, is great. For example, after increasing your population by, lets say 5000 people, new buildings unlock. These buildings help you build even a bigger city. To be honest though, it's slow and boring in the beginning. You can buy new square lands and increase the size of your city as your population is increasing. The economy isn't as hard as it is in SimCity so you can easily gain money. My only complaint is that you cannot buy all of these lands but fortunately there is a mod that can allow you to do that. Also, there aren't natural disasters but now they will soon add it as you can see from the DLC list! Can't wait for it!Enjoy and have fun building your own city!*Hint*: Use underground highway tunnels and roundabouts and connect them to another roundabout on the ground level so your traffic wont be so jammed. Also, dont make intersections so close to each other so there wont be frequent jams.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2015
												TL;DR: spending hours trying to work around bugs, get frustrated, not worth time time beyond getting a simple clogged city. Fixing it is very frustrating, or even impossible, due to bugs, and requires tearing it down and retrying- spending budget and time. Bad results and frustration are the reward for understanding this game's "logic".  There are however, other (non road) solutions for traffic problemsAlthough the game is fun at first, quickly, you realize you _NEED_ one way roads (because there is a bug where cars _always_ stop even if by every rule and logic THEY DO have priority.) and thus overpasses to get these connected. Having just come from a session of FAILING to construct workable overpasses about 20 times in a row, I am done with this game.Every time I get a road constructed the way I like it, it tends to be constructed wrong direction. This means I have to change the direction, but- with my overpasses- I  get a mesage I have no room. So I tear it down, try again, repeat X20.When it finally works, it looks like a piece of crap.Since there is no 'mixed' review I have no idea to vote it up or down. I'm conflicted.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												I have been patiently waiting for this game for months. Now, finally it's out. I am beyond satisfied! Admittedly the bar was low after the fiasco that is Cities:XXL (Focus Home Interactive), and the highly publicized issues SimCity (2013) had. That being said, this game vaulted over this bar like a human stepping over ants who are playing limbo. Clearly analogies aren't my strength, but this isn't the point! The point is, you should buy this game for several reasons. * It's fun as hell. I mean, that's number one by far.* It is inexpensive compared to AAA titles by big douchey companies. If you're on the fence, bite the bullet. Especially if you like city building games like SimCity or CitiesXL. This blows them out of the water.* The developers (Colossal Order) made this game out of a passion for the genre. This really shows in the detail of the game.* It's moddable/customizable. Amazingly so. Within two hours of the game there were over 200 entries on the workshop. That is how open they were about this game to modders before it was released.  I don't want to rant too much because I am clearly a happy player. I never really write reviews for games, but I felt the need to do so for this one. Get it and enjoy, you won't regret it!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Very enjoyable game, 4.5/5 or 9/10.+Nice enough graphics give enough realism.+Zoning works well with fill, square or circle.+Hundreds if not thousands of models so even the tiniest zones can be filled.The negatives are mostly nitpicks, but it must be brought to the attention of you, the reader.-Motorways/Highways. So if you have traffic backing up onto a motorway, why do people who do not want to come off there stay in the 1st lane? I'm sorry, but you are an idiot if you sit in lane 1 in a queue waiting to come off at a later point.-General traffic flow. As a Brit, I set it so traffic travels on the left, but it applies to both. If you're on the outside trying to turn to the outside, and they are on the inside trying to turn to the inside, YOU CAN BOTH GO AT THE SAME TIME!-Six lane roads. Similarly to above, traffic in lanes 2 and 3 stop if someone wants to join lane 1. Just use One Way 2 Lane roads, they work much more effectively. Also, if you have a road joining to head northbound, it does not interrupt southbound.-Roundabouts. Everything about them. As above, people in lane 2 wait for someone coming into lane 1. Traffic annoyance.-Proximity. Again, these are nitpicks, but they need to be sorted. If you have your 9 2x2km chunks all in a line and have services (for example, ambulance) at both ends, why do the ambulance drivers from one end even consider crossing through the busiest city in this instance of game to help someone with a cold at the other side? I have caught ambulance drivers crossing over 3 chunks of land to get to a midly ill patient when the patient lives NEXT DOOR TO A HOSPITAL! We need proximity priority!As I said, these are nitpicks. However, when you want to create a well-planned city and the only thing dragging it down is the fact that people can't go from left to left and right to right on the same junction at the same time, causing the entire motorway to clog up all the way out of your city boundries, it's rather annoying.I would still recomend the game though, because it's just plain damn fun. Let's not forget the game is still in early access and even if this guide is putting you off buying, get it none the less so the devs can fix the bugs earlier!

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												The review is this:  All the good stuff from SC5, none of the bad.  Where you got all of the bad stuff from SC5, Skylines has improved it to where it works.I am not writing this to badmouth SC5, I spent hundreds of hours playing it and enjoyed it for the most part except for the major concerns players had:No single highway in/out of your city causing major traffic bottlenecks.  The game allows you to expand your city to larger areas (Major concern of SC5 players).  The game includes Metro stations unlike SC5.  As far as public transportation you can not only place them but plan their routes like Cities in Motion.When you build roadways it will grid out exactly the depth of your city buildings construction of what you zone next to the road.  The highways are reconstructable to your liking.  The road tool to create curved roads was a little bit confusing on how to make the desired curved effect at first, but after a little while of experimenting it is not difficult and a much stronger mechanic then SC5.The thing I like the most is you are unable to construct High Density areas right at start.  You must start with Low Density and earn by population growth the higher density/metropolis buildings expected to see in a major city vs. a small town, i.e. small towns don't have nuclear power plants.  Civs will sort of trickle into your city little by little instead of having a massive population boom which undercuts your public services.All in all it is exactly what everyone was hoping for from SC5.For all the DLC complainers, I also own SC5 Cities of Tomorrow and found that enjoyable with all its problems, although I won't buy any more SC5 DLC's, if Skylines releases any DLC's I will be purchasing them as the developers obviously have learned from the catastrophic release of SC5 online play is not required.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												I keep calling this game SimCity inadvertently.  No, not in reference to the misfire from 2013.  Instead this game brings me back to the kind of fun I had playing the SimCity games of the past.Five days in after buying the game and I'm st ill building my first city.  After spending 18 hours (eep) I've expanded its borders as far as it will go, I've built a couple of the big unlockables, and I see no reason to stop with this city for now.There are issues with the game but it's phenominally good fun, intuitive, pretty good looking (even if not as polished as SimCity '13) and most important of all: there are no gamebreaking issues.  This is the best citybuilder in over a decade, and it continues the genre in fine tradition.Back to the issues...It could use more anti aliasing and the tilt-shift effect isn't as good as SimCity '13s.  These are minor quibbles.Road traffic doesn't seem to effectively use all lanes but once you learn some tricks to laying out your roads you can mitigate some of the traffic issues.  In this regard it's still better than SimCity '13.Rail traffic seems to be the wonkiest thing I've encountered.  Trains keep getting jammed up and stopping without any clear indication of where they're trying to go.  I may have made mistakes in laying out the tracks and stations so I'm still trying to figure out if this is something I've caused but something just feels off.Dealing with dead bodies and trash takes some getting used to, traffic can hold up their removal (and police, ambulances and firetrucks).  Abandoned buildings are also a bit of a nuisance because you are encouraged to bulldoze them, but they also seem to take care of themselves if there's demand for growth (they'll get torn down and rebuilt automatically).  That said leaving them up if there's not demand reduces the happiness/land value of the immediate area so bulldozing is a good idea unless they turn around quickly.TLDR: This game is $30, awesome fun, works great, active and extensive modding community.  BUY IT!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												Fantastic game!Anyone who's played SimCity before will have an idea what to expect here. Start out with a small town town, slowly build it up, generate funds and expand your city. The game is immersive straight off the bat, with a gental learning curve. It's the sort of game that will suck you right in, with hours going by without you noticing it. You'll spend your day thinking about modifications you're going to make when you get home. It's really that good.The game works by permitting development through the zoning of land. Different zones will permit different kinds of development. It's all held together by a road network (and later on a subway/train/plane network) that you'll constantly have to plan for and tweak. Services such as sewerage, water, electricity as well as services such as garbage, police, firefighters, ambulances, morgues, parks and education are all accounted for. It's a game of balance, a bit of that here a bit of that there. As the City grows, the game rewards you with more zones, services, buildings, etc, slowly dripping you the goodies as you progress rather than overwhelming you at the start.The game is super accessible, and whilst punishing earlier on, is rather easy once the ball gets rolling. My girlfriend had a go and succsesfully set up a city on her own.Whilst the game is super amazing, like every game it has it's minor problems. There is a lack of an endgame. Once you hit a certain point, it feels almost like a last section of the game is missing. Super high residential, mega-matropolis expansion pack please, with plenty more features! Furthermore, whilst I view the easy difficulty as a positive, many will feel the lack of challenge once the money starts to roll in. Roads play an important part of the game, but feel very volatile and hit/miss when placing them in complicated patterns. I feel like these things will likely be addressed over time as the game matures and mods set in. The workshop is already looking plentiful despite a recent release.Must-buy game, definately will be top 3 games of the year, especially with all this AAA+ trash that gets released these days.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												In 2014 EA and Maxis tried to jump on the train again continue the huge success of SimCity 4 with their new game SimCity(2014) but didnt manage to please the community due to small maps, huge server issues on release date, online pressure and overpriced DLC's.This year things are going to change the city building genre entirely - Paradox Interactive and Colossal Order are publishing Cities: Skylines and get immediately hit scores on sales!The game offers a huge map, which was the most important point that a modern city building game should deliver with even more extended space through several mods from the Steam Workshop. Also the game itself looks nice and offers a good usability for players. The  interface looks nice and most things in the game are already balanced.But now to the greatest part about this game: It's going to get further developed with more content updates and even a chance on multiplayer mode which would mean that SimCity is going to be completely useless. With an growing community and even an subreddit ( https://www.reddit.com/r/CitiesSkylines ) this game is a great start for game industrie into the new year 2015.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												this review is gonna be in 2 parts ( the game itself and comparing it to other City builders games)PART 1:  the game itself.Cities Skyline is a City builder game,  it runs smoothly  on  most machines but not on older ones or laptops , it requires allot of power to run. the game only have 1 mode which is build your own city.  u manage the needs of the citizens from electricity education and other services.  until you build a city big enough to expand and manage the traffics ...etcthe Price tag is acceptable for what the game offers. if u are new to these type of games its a good entire point. the end game is lack luster though but if u reached that level u alreay have inversted 40-60 hours inOverall its worth while. so I recommend it as it's the best city builder game available on steam.--------------PART 2 : Comparison to other city builder games. 1- SimCity5 (2013)the game UI is very similar which is nice, cause u don't need to relearn stuff from scratch . the game graphics in cities skyline is kinda better. but almost similar to Simcity.cities skylines have very Huge building area compared to simCity Which has some major Pros  and cons at the same time.what simcity was aiming at when they did give u small areas is to give the players more challenge on how to manage their city as u cannot build everything in one city thus increasing the replayablily  of the game. where in cities skylines u only need to build 1 city and manage it. there are no neighboring cities to interact with.also in SimCity5 have online multiplayer mode. as u can play with your friends making the best use of your cities co-op to build a huge workplace the benefit the entire region.unlike cities skylines the end game is lackluster. I only spend playing  40 hours and already built everything in the city reached the final stage and have no problems with my city. only build cemeteries all over the place.only real issue with simcity5 is their launch disaster .[so the final verdict is that simCity5 is far more superior version than cities skylines]2- cities XL at first i thought this is another installment of that franchise . but i was wrong.  if we look at these 2 games Cities XL is way more complicated than this game. overly complected and their UI is messy  unlike cities Skyline where it runs more smoothly than that game. Cities XL do not offer expansions of the cities but gives you Huge area to play with. u can still interact with other cities using Token system.  but beyond that nothing els.from my experience with both games I prefer Cities: Skylines over Cities XL series.

It came out day one with steam mod support and embraces the community and its feedback.  This is the greatest city builder in years and perhaps in the last decade and was priced to make this a no brainer.  Don't hesitate and buy this game now!  10/10

												Cities Skylines is a modern city builder with many possibilities. For large scale projects you can build a busy bustling city with airport, freight train stations and metro stops galore, or for something more intimate you can create a quaint country village or a farming community.With so many options and possibilities you may think that the game would be overwhelming, but with features unlocking as you go along, you are introduced to what you need to know in good time.Little fun additions like 'Chirpy' is a great way for your residents to give feedback to you, the Mayor of the city.  More and more mods appear every day making this a versatile, fun and intricate simulator.  Highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												this review is gonna be in 2 parts ( the game itself and comparing it to other City builders games)PART 1:  the game itself.Cities Skyline is a City builder game,  it runs smoothly  on  most machines but not on older ones or laptops , it requires allot of power to run. the game only have 1 mode which is build your own city.  u manage the needs of the citizens from electricity education and other services.  until you build a city big enough to expand and manage the traffics ...etcthe Price tag is acceptable for what the game offers. if u are new to these type of games its a good entire point. the end game is lack luster though but if u reached that level u alreay have inversted 40-60 hours inOverall its worth while. so I recommend it as it's the best city builder game available on steam.--------------PART 2 : Comparison to other city builder games. 1- SimCity5 (2013)the game UI is very similar which is nice, cause u don't need to relearn stuff from scratch . the game graphics in cities skyline is kinda better. but almost similar to Simcity.cities skylines have very Huge building area compared to simCity Which has some major Pros  and cons at the same time.what simcity was aiming at when they did give u small areas is to give the players more challenge on how to manage their city as u cannot build everything in one city thus increasing the replayablily  of the game. where in cities skylines u only need to build 1 city and manage it. there are no neighboring cities to interact with.also in SimCity5 have online multiplayer mode. as u can play with your friends making the best use of your cities co-op to build a huge workplace the benefit the entire region.unlike cities skylines the end game is lackluster. I only spend playing  40 hours and already built everything in the city reached the final stage and have no problems with my city. only build cemeteries all over the place.only real issue with simcity5 is their launch disaster .[so the final verdict is that simCity5 is far more superior version than cities skylines]2- cities XL at first i thought this is another installment of that franchise . but i was wrong.  if we look at these 2 games Cities XL is way more complicated than this game. overly complected and their UI is messy  unlike cities Skyline where it runs more smoothly than that game. Cities XL do not offer expansions of the cities but gives you Huge area to play with. u can still interact with other cities using Token system.  but beyond that nothing els.from my experience with both games I prefer Cities: Skylines over Cities XL series.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game


YouTube™ Video: Cities Skylines: Quick Look (City building Simulation, gameplay, and review) 

			Views: 687		

			Cities Skylines: Quick Look (City building Simulation, gameplay, and review) Is Cities: Skylines the Sim City we've all been waiting for? "Quick Look" is our short impression series of various games.		

Cities Skyline gives the player everything you would expect from a proper modern city builder game. It has expansive maps, detailed cities and population, intricate micro management, yet it's accessible and easy to pick up.Graphically the game is a looker. With detailed models, atmospheric filtering effects, and all the little things happening when you zoom in, the game look and feels alive. The audio design is immersive with the hustle and bustle of the crowds and traffic pulling the player in. Though the music seems over dramatic and on default settings it's strangely loud, but it does the job at keeping the player company.Mechanically the game can get deep when you learn all the details, yet the basics to get going is pretty easy. With that said, the game still requires a degree of self research as all the finer details in it's mechanics aren't always fully explained. Overall Cities: Skylines is a very enjoyable city builder, and at it's core, every thing I wanted from a modern Sim City.Pros:- Easy to learn- Lots of fine detail to micromanage- Great looking, very immersive- Supports mods- Huge map to build onCons:- Finer detail mechanics aren't always explained well- Some quality of life issues could use smoothing outCities: Skyline hours played at recording: 22Completion Status on Cities Skyline: N/AThis copy of Cities: Skyline was purchased on Steam

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Can't...Stop...Playinggggg!!!!Arrragh!I have to be honest that I pirated it before I purchased it. The reason is simple: I was skeptical whether a team consists of roughly 10 people would be able to deliver a game matches its price. You know, think about EA's SimTown...And that infamous Cities XXXXXXXL...Not trying to make excuse anyway. Just don't want to be let down.And after log into the game and start playing, it's like time slitting away from my palm. Normally in SimTown as long as you cover the city limit with buildings there will not be much point keep playing on it and in Cities XXXXXXL long before that it's going to lag to unplayable. So generally I will not be absorbed in it and will eventually lose interest and get a life. However in Cities: Skylines I have already obtained "Metropolitan" title and the city just looks astounding. There are much, much more buildings in my metro than you can ever build in SimTown or Cities XXL, nevertheless the game is still smooth like hell. I mean it. I'm using a Core i5 and GForce 750M laptop and the fan is blazing, but any camera pan/ rotate will be in order immediately. The mechanics is similar to simtown. Nothing can be blamed since simtown has already got a pretty good system, yet of course the bloody "seperate township“ has to be excluded. Notable differences include the induction of "Noise" and power grid, etc etc. The power grid system is a bit unrealistic since as long as your suburb is extended to the point you would like electricity to flow into you don't need to pull high-voltage wire to connect it to the power plant. Clearly it can not be achieved otherwise we'll not see utility poles around in our daily life.  (Sorry to be pedantic but I'm doing electrical engineering :( You can open an economy panel and tune tax rate/ policies however this bit is oversimplified IMHO. For instance there is not much noticeable effect if you change the tax rate for houses except your income. The graphic is not bad. You can complain it to be rough and undetailed, but I would rather want smoothness over a bit of detail, since with the game itself lag like s*** nobody will ever interested in zooming in to examine the minutiae of the city. Tweeting system is freshening but annoying in late game. Developer might want to expand the dictionary.This game is even equipped with a tool to form the terrain your city will be situated on. Even with a tool to enable importing of geographical data to automatically generate height offset! You know, I am currently using double screens, with google map on one screen and the game on the other, trying to create a city of Melbourne. And after terraforming, I am going to copy the city of Melbourne, street by street, building by building, onto it. What if you can't find the exact building in the game, you may ask.Create it then. This game has building creation tool. Pretty much like it in Spore. See, the replayability is vast. How amazing will it be, if you duplicate your hometown onto it, and do a bit of experiment on it maybe? Blast your home away from it? Merge this road with another to see the impact on traffic? Do whatever you like. It's your city.20/10TL;DR : BUY IT.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Cities Skyline is a great game if you like to build modern cities. The road system is incredibly well done. I like how they chose to link zones directly to roads. Everything feels neat and clean. It has in-game tools for creating your own maps and game assets. You can create, for instance, a custom power plant with your own model or build it out of pre-existing models and determine it's stats such as cost and power output. Best of all your creations can easily be posted to the steam workshop and the game is incredibly mod-friendly. I like almost everything about the game; in fact my only major complaint is that the game is too easy. It's virtually impossible to "lose" at cities skylines. Even if you play like a complete idiot, going bankrupt is very rare unless you want it to happen. You can just have insanely high tax rates and let people move in, get totally reamed, leave angrily only to come back later. You could be the worst mayor who ever lived and make millions with ease. With the exception of losing a valuable structure to a fire or something, there's virtually no consenquences to anything you do. Some might say it's not about winning or losing, aiming instead for effeciency, but there's a fine line between "min-maxing" (making your city as effective as you can) and having no challenge whatsoever. Sim City 3000, for instance, was much harder to get into the green; requiring you carefully plan your city or to plague it with casinos and toxic waste dumps (which were unique buildings you can only build when given the opprotunity to do so) in order to get ahead. Whenever you had enough money to build something big, it really mattered. You had to decide if you wanted a new hospital or some reinforcement to your educational system - and if you would have enough income to support your new object. Expanding your city size and adding more zones was also a very careful decision players made in Sim3K, because if you could not adequately support a new burst of population it could mean trouble. There were legitimate consequences to your actions - cranking up tax rates won't just make people leave, they will riot and start fires. Even with Skyline's "hard" mode which is tucked away as an optional mod you can turn on (right next to infinite money) the game feels way too simple at times.Ultimately if you just wanna mess around and build stuff, Skylines is obviously a massive upgrade to the original sim games - but it's kind of terrible as an actual game that imposes challenges and problems you have to overcome. With modding, though, I'm sure the community could find a way to make the game more difficult. The game has a good soundtrack (pretty sure I hear some references to older SimCity music in there, too), cozy aesthetics and enough variety to keep most players entertained for at least 20 to 30 hours. Definitely a good purchase for both people who like city builders and those who are new to the genre.Rating: B+PS: Death to chirper.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												Best sim city type game since Sim City 4 Rushhour,  without question.  Obviously that does not say much when you compare what has come out since SC4 but still it is a great game.  Roads that are curvable, the ability to make your own buildings (think BAT tool in SC4 but a ton easier to figure out and use), custom bus lines, custom train lines, custom subway lines, taxis, ferry service, expandable roads, click and follow cars/pedistrians ...It is not perfect mind you, the ability to bulldoze and flatten land does not exist (well it does on slopes with low % grades, but you want to flatten a mountain, that is not happening as no option to do it).Also, once you reach 8 expansions of your city limits that is it.  No option to buy land past that (at least that I have found).  That said 8 extensions is a lot but would be nice to build more.  Right now I have a city at 110K population though it has been there for a while.  Thing is there is a huge online community that has gives tons of FREE downloadable content which makes the game interesting.  Currently I am on 92 plus hours and still loving it.  Just downloaded the expansion AFTER DARK (that costs money in case you were wondering) but it gives more eye-candy and transport options.I currently give it an 8.5/10 which says a lot as it is rare I  ever give a game 8 or higher.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Cities: Skylines experience in one word? Extraordinary.Cities: Skylines not only offers breath taking visuals, it also features captivating game play by implementing the most moddable options we've seen in a city sim to date. Without a doubt the asset editor is probably one of the most brilliant ideas included with this game. Ever play a city sim where some buildings are not to your liking, require too much space or you just don’t like the general set out of them? Not anymore, you can change absolutely everything to suit your preferences and gameplay style. Once you get taken into your citizen’s messages via chirper it is unbelievably easy to lose time whilst playing this game. I cannot tell you how much time I’ve spent re-routing traffic in order to get it working smoothly, so don’t be surprised if a quick fix for heavy traffic areas become a grand plan that takes more than the quick couple of minutes you had anticipated before starting. Cities: Skylines has completely revolutionised the whole genre of city sims. Keep in mind this is just the start of something great, I cannot wait to see what else can come of this genre after such a phenomenal milestone. 11/10

A combination of the good parts of one city sim with another along with new features not yet made in any of those sim.The bad point ?- Localization suffers some typos/mistakes here and there, but it's still alright.- Tunnels can't be made ... A mod to fix that ? *winks at modders* - No building customization (giving it a continent style over another) ... Again, modders are there for that !The good point ?- Even after 4 hours, I still didn't fill the map and yet I could expand it more.- Easy to understand.- Traffic sim is quite alright, even though vehicles sometimes don't use all the road lanes for some reasons.- Limitation ? What's that ? You're limitless ! Even doing a highway across your city is possible if you wanted to. (Although I don't see the point of doing it ...)

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												TL;DR The game is a nice leveling sandbox hampered by unintuitive gameplay, unusual traffic decisions, limited building styles, and confusing UI decisions. The less micro you like in a game, the more you will like this one. If you don't like being on rails while you play and want to have fine tunning controls, this game is probably not for you.Edit: As of the most recent update, while many things have been improved, the core complaints below has not been addressed. I do hope they address at least some of this, but for now everything below is still accurate. I have also clarified the maximum zoning size.Unfortunately, I have to move this review to not recommending for now. Once the rose colored glasses come off, there are some major issues that need fixing before I recommend this game to anyone but the most forgiving of individuals. The game is pretty good and can be a lot of fun...but those who haven't bought it yet will probably be heavily annoyed by the many frustrations this game also provides. Issue #1 Traffic. People will tell you there is nothing wrong with traffic, but there really is, and I can explain that problem in a sentence. Cars are always moving. Car leaves origin, travels towards destination, returns to origin, and heads to destination again. Because of this loop always running, there is no way to fix the traffic problem. People, businesses, factories work on cycles in real life. What's more, they are not constantly productive. Some forms of agriculture produce goods daily, some weekly, some monthly, and some are a once a year thing. Major comercial sectors time their shipments to arrive at night when there is limited traffic and thus deliveries are more efficient. With no day/night cycle and thus no low traffic/heavy traffic cycles the game punishes otherwise efficient designs by having only one mode of traffic, heavy. This is what creates all of the other traffic problems observed. Sure you can build around these problems, and there are many people who gain great pleasure from dealing with such. If that is you, then this game is probably for you. Otherwise, there really needs to be cyclic traffic flows in this game. Low traffic weekends in industrial areas, high traffic commercial. Residential needs to be low traffic most of the day.Issue #2 Limitations. There is a lot missing from this game. Asthetics, public building options, utilities, even auto constructed building have very limited and generic asthetics. Because of this, you will quickly find that one city looks just like any other quickly leaving the game feeling very cookie cutter. Having multiple building styles that alternate every 10 years or so would go a long way to fixing this and creating a feeling of a progressing city. Mods can only help in a limited way here. This is a fix that really needs to come from the devs. Issue #3 Zoning. There is only one way this game zones, that is automatically as you lay your roads. You can color in the blocks representing what can be built, but no matter what, you can not define the shape of the area you want constructed in. This forces you away from more organic designs as the game attempts to create numerous obnoxious shapes when a simple rectangle would have done much better. Such choices are not in your hand, and there are no creative work arounds as zoning is immediatly deleted when you remove a road, and anything built on it. Even if you are just trying to fix something and all buildings would still be with road access where they need it. Fix, let the player zone an area as industrial, commercial, or industrial then let them build the roads afterwards. The game can then highlight areas wasted due to lack of road access. This would allow for more organic, fun designs. As the game currently exist, and as a reply to "NGB" the image below represents how it currently works.


Visual explanation of zoning behavior odditites 
Community Created Artwork for Steam Artwork
By: agreeksailor

			This image goes along with my review for Cities: Skylines. This was in response to an individual telling me I had missed certain UI elements. The inset explains everything else that requires explanation.		


Issue #4 Building Footprint Sizes. Thanks to the way the game is created, you will never have large flowing fields of green on the outskirts of your city. Every single building has a maximum size of 4X4. Yes there are limited buildings that are larger you can construct manually, but you will never see large areas develop on their own. This is a direct result of how zoning is handled. Fix for this, fix zoning, then let the building bases have larger sizes.Issue #5 The Fan Base. This is going to be the number 1 reason I am not going to recomend this game to most people. Currently, the fans are to put it mildly, hostile to any criticisms of the game. Collosal Order has made no mistake and can do no wrong, so any issues you see are your fault and that's all there is. This isn't a problem in itself, it's a problem because there are so many like this that people with real issues can't talk about them because these fans derail threads and stop any form of productive discussion on the proplems. This is a good game that needs work, it is not a priceless work of art that needs to be preserved in its release state. There absolutely are design decisions in this title that need to be reconsidered. When you have so many that attack those that would suggest this game needs more work you can't have the discussions that need to happen. What's more, it's hard to get help when the fans are so abusive. There are many aspects of this game that just are not intuitive, and there is a significant portion of this fan base that will leave you not even wanting to use the forums. This is the real shame of the success of this game. This game was almost too successful for its own good.Edit: A screenshot from the comments on this review which shows an example of the response criticism of this game recieves. Notice that no points are refutted or discussed, just a blanket everyone else thinks this game is wonderful. I think he may have also been trying to criticize me...but the jab seems to have gone over or under my head.


De-constructive Feedback 
Community Created Artwork for Steam Artwork
By: agreeksailor

			oldeguy provides yet another example of why any discussion that doesn't praise the game is difficult to have.		


There are an abundance of places where you can read the virtues of this game. This is the devil advocate review that only focuses on the bad or at a minimum the questionably implemented features that detract from the experience. The bird is not an issue to make you not buy the game, however, you will be punished for modding it out by turning off achievments. While there is a mod to re-enable achievments, what will probably start nagging you is how you have to keep downloading mods to fix questionable design decisions. An ingame option to turn off all nag screens and the bird is not too much to ask. These are the basic things that serve to move this from a must have to a marginal recomendation depending on whether you can ignore the issues and are willing to work around the ones that can't be ignored. For me the answer is no, which is why I have stopped playing for now.I am aware that the devs have planned a number of improvements to the game, if any of those improvements affect the issues I have highlighted, I will gladdly return to fix this review and its recomendation status. While I have highlighted the fans as the #1 issue for me not recommending the game, it doesn't really factor in. I hope people that applies to read it and reply proving me right, even better, maybe they read it and realize they could be a little more civil to their fellow humans. Who knows? If any 2 of the above issues become resolved I will move this review to a solid recommend. If this game goes on sale for $15.00 dollars, then that is also a solid recommend from me even with the issues.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												Eight hours in and I've been really enjoying it so far. It's very much inspired by the recent Sim City title (the UI is pretty much pulled directly from Sim City) but it makes some very important improvements. The cities are MUCH larger once your city grows and you can expand to additional squares. The game does a better job following individual citizens around the city. Also, the Steam Workshop support is great. There have already been a lot of neat mods and additional assets created and the game has only been out a few days. Also, the price point is better than Sim City's at launch, so that always helps too. If you were disappointed by EA/Maxis' title, check out this one instead. If you haven't played a city simulator game in a long time, this is the one I'd recommend picking up.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
Initial ImpressionsWell, I can honestly say that I was looking forward to it. Many comparisons made to Simcity, stemming from a place of fondness of course. While the "Sim" brand will always have a place on my gaming rig (I miss you so much Sim Tower![en.wikipedia.org]), Cities: Skylines delivers on many levels.Current ConsiderationsOkay, lets be succinct: I'm wringing every last bit of playability of the vanilla version for this game before I move on. It's just that good!Future FixationsCities: Skylines has an asset editor to create your own mods in-game or you can import your own models. The modding community just blossomed within hours of the game release. Without a doubt, I will be using these creative mods in the future and quite possibly creating a few myself.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Its been more than a decade but, 8 hours into the game, I think Simcity 4 finally has a worthy successor, Cities Skylines.This game offers;- A decent artstyle, the first decent replacement of the 2d Simcity style.- Much greater infrastructure detail, customisation & ease of use over SC4- The traffic model appears more realistic and your actions have logical impacts on it - Good modding support and tools- Whilst the scale, in terms of population, is much lower than SC4 it appears more realistic and accurate- I would estimate the maximum city size is 2x the size of the larger city tile in SC4The only negative thing I can say about the game is that it is very difficult to fail, however its something I'm willing to overlook. The unlocking of buildings/services/functions as your city progresses does not feel limiting but serves a vital role in ensuring less experienced/casual players find the game easier to play.90/100Only improvements I can think of would be;Adding a Region, allowing cities to interactAdding multiplayer region or easy way to exchange city tiles.I hope paradox will consider these improvements for the sequel, they are certainly on a distinguished road.

												Hey look.... a city building game where I can build actual cities, instead of small towns, and I can even expand them!At first I was a little hesitant about buying the game, after being so dissapointed with the recent Simcity, but I bought the game none the less, and I am glad I did. Cities: Skylines have thus far been a very enjoyable experience. I have put just about 14 hours into the game, at the time of this review and I don't really have anything bad to say about the game.Gameplay:+ The difficulty feels just about right, and it seems to increase along with the size of your city.+ The game WILL punish you, if you make the wrong decisions, and let them be for too long.+ I enjoy having to balance my ever changing budget+ Even after 14 hours of gameplay, I still feel I have alot to discover about the game.- Having to delete abandoned buildings one by one, can be very tedious, boring and frustrating.- Upgrading and changing road types could work better.- Elevating roads, making bridges and then connectiong them to other roads can be a bit tricky.The game:+ The game runs smooth on my high-end rig+ The graphics are great considering the small download size+ The game seems to run Fullscreen (Windowed Mode) by default.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
 A real feat...	This is the game Simcity was trying to be. If you know and have played Simcity, then you know what I mean. It was a brilliant effort, that was somehow hindered, perhaps by EA's greed. This is the best parts of Simcity, but so much more. Everything is done... well, just about perfectly - and by a team that, compared to Maxis's workforce, is tiny. I'd do a list of pros and cons about now, but the list of pros for this game might be too long. Instead...The most brilliant things this have over Simcity: - MASSIVE cities. This one can't be avoided. You start in a square roughly the size of Simcity's. You can then buy another EIGHT. So, yeah, it's 9 times the size of Simcity. You can have even more (25!) with the help of a mod, which brings me on to my next point... - Mods. And Steam Workshop integration. I don't think I've played a game where adding mods was so easy and fluid, and grabbing assets from the workshop is brilliant - particularly for intersections. And on that matter, adding your own is so simple too. - Fantastic simulation. I don't really know how Simcity managed to get this wrong, when Cities gets it so right. Simcity's glassbox engine was cool to look at, I admit, but... In Simcity, people woke up in the morning, went to work at the nearest job they could find, then went to the nearest home they could find afterwards and repeated the same every morning. In Cities, every person has a name, a car, a house, a job... It's fantastic. Additionally, water simulation is pretty neat too. It's the only game where you can actually drain a river by pumping all the water out, or flood a city by building a dam. A few minor niggles that don't bother me at all, really: - I kinda miss the specialisation thing from Simcity. If, like me, you liked that, you'll probably miss it a bit too. - The graphics, while excellent, aren't quite as perfect as in Simcity. Something's a little off, so I think it just needs a few more settings in the options menu. However, you can pretty much have whater you like using mods too, so... not really much of an issue. - Traffic AI. Now, Simcity had the same problem at launch really. It's just not smart enough. The main problem is things like hearses, picking up jobs on the opposite side of the city, while there's a dead person waiting for transport right next to the crematorium. But, there's also problems with lanes. The AI just don't use them efficiently (even naturally) enough. Fix this. Please. - My train network gets jammed up. Not because of my rail design, but because of the rail design beyond the map, which seems a bit unfair.So, if you like city builders, I can't reccomend this game more. This is the new definitive city building game, and I think it'll remain that way for quite a while.9.999/10 (fix traffic for the 10/10)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												About six thousand years ago when the dinosaurs ruled the Earth, I discovered this game called "SimCity", and it was good. So insanely good that I played almost every incarnation of the game for the next 20 years, except for the really horrible "social" versions, which were terribly dumbed down.Then after the great flood washed away the dinosaurs, and took with it the last of EA's great developers and designers, we few surviving life-long SimCity addicts were left playing SimCity 4: Rush Hour for long year after year, hoping for the light to shine down from the heavens and impart on us the great knowledge, wisdom and truth of a brilliant new version of SimCity. That's when EA shoveled on us the massing stinking pile of dinosaur dung that was the "new" SimCity (aka SimCity 5), and lo, it was dark, ominous, horrible, and shockingly tiny. And DRM-restricted. And generally awful to the point where we all agreed SimCity was forever dead, killed by a greed-driven troll in the dark mountain keep of Electronicus Artus.And then Cities: Skylines appeared. And there was much joy and celebration! And lo, it was not only good, it was GREAT, and instantly assumed the torch of being the true spiritual successor of SimCity 4. If there had been a real SimCity 5 in the spirit of its predecessors, then Cities: Skylines is that game.True, Skylines doesn't have all of the options that SC4:RH did, but clearly the developers are on the right path and doing the right things. Tunnels are now in, and I honestly feel that these folks "get it". I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a true spiritual successor to SimCity 4: Rush Hour. Stick with these guys, it feels like they're on the right path and could grow this game into something truly amazing in time.
