content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												This doesn't just hit a home run, Cities SKYLINES bats it out of the park into orbit and to the moon Alice... and then some.9 Hours into this game and I just can't put it down.  NO LAG, NONE, ZIP, ZERO, this game runs SMOOTH (specs below).Started my first city today, messed about for 5-15 minutes getting the feel, then threw that away to start fresh now knowing what I need to do.  Having been playing 'Simcity' since the SNES version was released around 92 or so...Built roads, facilities, zoned as needed.  Plenty of options.  You purchase more map tiles as you go, they are part of your live city.  No loading/saving to access another tile.  This game is downright awesome with that expansion bit - they nailed it.  I mean NAILED IT.  This is the TRUE SUCCESSOR TO SIMCITY 4 DELUXE.  THIS IS WHAT SC2013 SHOULD HAVE BEEN.  I'll write this again so everyone can see it. THIS IS THE TRUE SUCCESSOR TO SIMCITY 4 DELUXE, THIS IS WHAT SIMCITY 2013 SHOULD HAVE BEEN.  IF YOU LOVED SIMCITY 4 AND PLAY IT TO THIS DAY, BUY THIS.  ENTIRELY WORTH IT, VERY AFFORDABLE!  There was Simcity on the SNES and pc.  Then there was Simcity 2000 on DOS 6.x on the venerable amd 486 66 ...Then there was Simcity 3000... but 2000 and 3000 didn't quite capture the magic that Nintendo put into the SNES version.  For so many years I kept that SNES and Simcity... and then Simcity 4 came out... it was good, but not until Rush Hour expansion was it great.  Rush Hour combined into the Original was also marketed as the Deluxe version.  Adding in the NAM mod to Simcity 4 deluxe made the game really awesome if you were into highway design, and really could excell at traffic management.  Cities XL was buggy, and laggy... and very vague (and therefor frustrating).  Cities XXL had promise but just did not deliver beyond multicore enhancements - it was generally everything (bad with the good) that XL was... re-wrapped into a new package.  Simcity 2013 had promise, but EA's greedyness and needless DRM and small city sizes/day 1 bugs really got the game off to a bad start.  You just couldn't build to your imagination's content like you could in Simcity 4 Deluxe - beyond the initial degridding.  Simcity 2013 was like a demo, a demo of something that could have been so awesome...  but last week... last week I heard some bad news.Maxis, to us City-Building afficianados - was something quite dear - Maxis was shuttered.  The Sims (EU studio) live on, but Simcity, as we know it, was official pulled off life support and pronounced dead... and know I know why.This game.  GOD BLESS THESE DEVS, SKYLINES NAILS IT.  EVERYTHING.  5/5!!!There is SO much realism packed into this game, and many things I did not expect.Traffic management? Check!Ability to build with realism using roads/avenues/bypasses to hearts content? Check!Highways, offramps/onramps buildable?  Check!Multilevel bridge over bridge stuffs for super-snazzy interchanges?  Check! (Roundabout, cloverloaf, diamond, trumpet, freeform entirely -not just PREFABS only, if you like - your imagination and the space available is your only limit)Large expansion of the city as needed?  Check! (more with MOD support)64bit exe and NO memory leaks?  Check!GREAT graphics (for a city builder)?  Check!  [Directx 11 video card required under Windows!]Sufficient sound feedback and decent music?  Check!  (Music in non-intrusive, sound fx I have no complaints on)Good play control/movement/UI design?  Check!Mod support?  Well, not yet - but devs are promising it!Healthcare AND deathcare? EEK!  Check!Trains for passengers AND freight?  Check! Seaports for passengers AND freight?  Check!  (improves industrial demand)Airports to attract more tourists and connect you better to the outside world (and their money!!!)? Check!Ability to creat custom maps and a terrain editor (and importing greyscale heightmaps)? Check!Ability to build in sunny tropical climate, or the more northern latitudes (custom gfx, sun angle)? Check!Broad range of options to customize the game to your hardwares ability/disability?  Check!Alternative ways to solve the many problems you face, and the ability to see you have them? Check & double Check!!!Game breaking bugs?  Nope - not in over 9 hours into it... not anything I can see. No CTDs, no glitchyness, nothing.I could go on and on...  58,000+ people in the city, 6 million in the treasury and making a good income monthly.I just can't seem to want to stop playing or get bored of this... I am absolutely in shock at how good this game is. Simcity 4 Diehards, This is the game WE have been waiting for - do NOT hesitate!  NO REGRETS HERE!THIS GAME IS NOT AND IS NOT AFFILIATED WITH CITIES XL OR CITIES XXL IN ANY WAY/SHAPE/FORM, OTHER THAN IT BEING A CITY BUILDER, A GOOD ONE AT THAT, A REALLY REALLY GOOD ONE. There are only TWO reasons you should not buy this game. 1.) If you cannot afford it.  The price IS very reasonable - VERY REASONABLE.2.) If you have a video card that is not capable of DirectX 11.  Do not use Intel video, it's glitchy.That said, those on Intel-based laptops, you need to force this game to use the dedicated AMD or NVIDIA gpu, otherwise it will be slow and glitchy defaulting to the laptop's Intel gfx.  You can do this from inside AMD Catylist, or Nvidia Control Panel.  You can find these solutions in the discussion forums here on Steam.  INTEL GFX IS NOT SUPPORTED.As stated above, hardware specs are here:i7 4790k @ 4.6ghz on Asus Maximus Hero VII Z97 Chipset motherboard16gb 2400mhz ram (8gb x2) corsair dominatorAsus Radeon 7850 2gb gddr5 [1ghz core] video card with Direct CU II cooling (the don't-ever-hear-it cooler)Dual Toshiba SSD drives in Raid 0 for OS & Games, for quick loading (almost zero load times. maybe a second or two)Soundblaster X-fi Titanium pro soundcardFractal Arc XL case with Seasonic 750 watt PSU, and Phanteks somethin'-14 red coolerI listed everything in the event someone wants to dupe the whole hardware config, game runs AWESOME.  NO LAG on HIGH settings.Seriously, get this game now.  You'll be glad you did.   The devs really got this one right.  Finally, A SIMCITY 4 REPLACEMENT!If you're a small kid with no money, do some extra chores for money!  Paint the dog, wash the lawn, mow the hedges, trim the carpet, vacuum the dishes, sweep the walls, scrub the garden, tiedye your white kittycat, ANYTHING to make money to buy this game (actually forget the bit with the cat, that might get you grounded, or worse, clawed and grounded).Can't wait to see what the NAM team does with this one :)--Cheers guys and good luck!  ... now if I can just kill that annoying little blue bird...***Laptop users DON'T forget if you have intel GFX to make sure this game uses the AMD or NVIDIA GPU!  Desktop users should be just dandy as this issue won't happen.  AGAIN, INTEL GFX IS NOT SUPPORTED AT THIS TIME/POSSIBLY EVER.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Wow, Cities: Skylines... Where to begin...- Firstly, this game is the game that EA's Simcity should have been, except about 1000 times better. More buildings, more options, better gameplay mechanics and generally more everything!- Secondly, The gameplay and the customisation feature of this game are truely its strong point. With thousands of Workshop items, assets and vechicles created by a community of dedicated fans that are added to your game with a simple click. This adds a whole new level to a game which no other rival city builder can truely compare to. Did I mention that these Workshop add-ons are FREE???- Thirdly, The Developers ACTUALLY CARE ABOUT THE GAME. That is one thing that EA missed on with Simcity, EA just rode the current of their popularity river that the Sim series has created and as soon as the game was released, the game was mostly left to cough, splutter and die due to its lack of new features, AI problems and repetitiveness. Simcity did see a few updates but nothing compared to the love this game has recieved from the developers.This game has problems though, it has to be said. I have experienced problems during my play time, mainly around the stability on my PC, especially seeing as I am not running your typical /r/pcmasterrace beast machine. Asides from the occational lapse of framerate, crashes can occur. In the past, I have been left with a few hours of progress wiped because of foolishly not saving my progress. Collosial Order seem to have fixed this as crashes seem to happen less frequently then it used to but I do still see a occasional drop of FPS in my game, but again, I am not running an epic PC. Thinking of it, this game is so addicting that I have had to force myself to save or enable autosave.But that's really it, a lot of pros and a few tiny cons. Cities: Skylines is a must have for gamers who like Simulation games, City Builders, Moddable games and a whole lot of mircomanaging.EDIT (25/11/'16): I highly recommend buying the game with the extra DLCs. Although it will set you back a bit more, you will be supporting future development of the game and the extra features are mostly worth it. Think of it as a virtual highfive to the devs.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												About time we have a good City Builder from a reputed company.After playing this for some time, here are some feedback compared to SimCity4: Deluxe.PRO:1. Game starts as expected. Build some roads, electric, water, and zones.  Bulldozing gives money back instead of costing money.You don't spend money to zone or re-zone.  You can easily lose if you screw up this part. A second failure point that can crop up at this stage is placing something now that creates a pollution hub later.2. There is a lot to manage but you start small - then as you get bigger, the more you need to manage. Progression feels good and appropriate for a game in this genre. Pacing is also smooth. The Pace is dictated by Milestones, as you reach certain goals in the game you get to purchase more land, unlock buildings and more upgrades.3.  Mods in this game are pretty good in their potential.  Anyone can make Assets or Maps.  4. There is enough to simulate to entertain you but there isn't too much depth.  The level of depth feels appropriate.  Not dumbed down by any means.5. Lots of potential room for DLC, Expansions and more content WITHOUT being stripped down to nothing.  This is not a half-game awaiting the rest in microtransactions. CON: No big flaws yet.  1. Some parts of the UI are primitive.  When you click to view Energy, Waste, Fire or Crime, it doesn't tell you how much money you are spending on it. So there is some juggling of one tab to the next.2. You cannot move or re-size the windows that open for you when you click buttons.3. The music could have a better presence.  It is a bit quiet and often I hear nothing but birds.4. "Forced" to start small and build big from scratch.  You "can cheat" if you like, but playing without cheats you cannot just start building a large city. Some people might dislike having the same starting situation evey single time on terms of what you can build and how you advance.Linear Progression is the rule of this Sandbox.  Fortunately, you can advance in a non-linear way. Overall:  9/10.  The only thing that could have made this game better is to have more control over the size of Zones - the "Zones" appear next to road types when you build roads. You don't place "zones." Once the road is placed and the "Zone Spot" appears next to the road, you may designate that as Residential, Commercial or Industial.This is the best City Builder on the market, period.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												Day One review:GET IT... it's awesome, does have a few glitches, but they will be worked out....DAY TWO UPDATE:Well I'm 18 hours in... I have noticed a few hiccups, I have 2 pc's, one @ Work one @ Home, The work pc is technically slower than my home pc, but loads Skylines quicker. Don't ask why IDK... Also, I was one of those people who subscribed to mods before release, bad move.. Most got duplicated instead of updated, and my game went bonkers, I had to remove each mod in game, which for some reason is a chore, you can only delete one at a time.. Also, gameplay, The core game is weird, and I hung around long enough to get a few acheivements, but I've switched over to Sandbox mode, why? because the finance model is flawed, I can have 10% tax on everyone and still lose money..  I will just play with unlimited funds & a few good unlimited resource mods.. The map editor could use a video tutorial, I have played games with map editors before, but for some reason this editor just doesn't feel as good as it could...So, definitely get this game it is better than SIMCITY & Cities XXL series.. just don't think it's all peaches & creme.. there are some head scratching moments... But CO is good about support for their games...Day 2 update part two:28 Hours in, I have ditched the base game mode for now, the MODS & Sandbox definitely save this game, I have built a city w/ 100,000 people in it, but still somehow, industry didn't have enough people to fill the jobs... REALLY? Also, building up for the monuments is pretty difficult if not somewhat impossible without mods.. I have unlocked 25 city tiles, and have laid out seperate districts, so in a sense, from some screenshots i posted it looks like a free form region builder, instead of the constrained regions of SIMCITY 2013.. I would be able to fill in all the gaps, but That could take a few more days, besides that, a full 2x2km section in my city is all railroads & highways.. I honestly can't see myself going back to no mods, not until some stupid routing bugs get squashed.. Why have 3-6 lane highways? The CIMS only use 1 freaking lane... But other than that, this game does beats the tar out of Simcity as a whole.. I can't see myself ever going back to SIMCITY 4 or 2013.. Skylines has definitely won me over... I am patiently awaiting TUNNELS & major bug fixes..

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Refreshing city building game that touches on the roots of the original Sim City games. As a complete package I would rate this game over Sim City and it's expansion pack "Cities of Tomorrow". Bigger zones to build out on, basically these equal the size of Sim City regions. Better road management options, better public transport option (subways!), Day/Night cycle based budgeting, mods, great graphics, overall a more complicated but more rewarding game.Couple of things it falls short on would be budgeting, while you have more fine tuned options to adjust your finances, it lacks the ability that Sim City has where you can indivualy reduce/increase funding to say schools. In Cities Skylines if you adjust the budget for Education it affects all schools, so for example one school may need more funding because it overcrowed. By increasing the funding to education it increases all school funding nore matter the type. So while I may now have enough money to suuport the Elementary school, my high school is now over funded. Region play is missing from Cities: Skyline but makes up for it in the size of maps. Plus the avaliability of terraforming and making your own map!Industry is handled better in Sim City than Cities: Skylines hands down. While in Sim City specializing in certain industries (Oil, Ore, etc..) has a progression type mechanic too it, you dont start out with all the goodies. In Skylines you more or less lay down Industry tiles, district it to whatever you're trying to produce (farms for instance) and just kind of let it go. No real interaction with it like there is with Industry in Sim City.In my personal opinion it's still a vastly more fun game and with Steam Workshop support the possiblities are endless!

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												It's been a long time since a really good City Builder has been on the market so every time there is a whisper of a new one being developed, fans of the genre like myself become eager with anticipation. Unfortunately, we have been left wanting for nearly a decade. Yes, it's been that long since a really decent sim has been released. Upon learning that one of my favorite publishers, Paradox Interactive, had a City Building simulation in the works I knew this was a game I could not wait to get my hands on. Paradox Interactive is known for being a leader in challenging and entertaining strategic games so I felt if anybody could do it right, they could. Having been able to test the game for almost a full week before its official release I can say that my trust was not misplaced. Cities Skylines is everything I hoped it would be. This is city building done right.I have played most every City Building game ever made and consider myself somewhat of an expert in the genre. Perhaps I am over-critical at times when it comes to my favorite gaming genre but it comes from the desire to find the Holy Grail in city sims. I can honestly say, Cities Skylines is far and above, the best city building simulation ever made. Period. Colossal Order has come up with a recipe that ingenuously combines just the right amount of simplistic game design with a flavorful amount of challenging gameplay to create a masterpiece. Fans of City Building simulations will definitely not want to miss grabbing this game.There is a very realistic feel to this game. It's not just about throwing out color-coded building zones, but more about true city management. Do things right and your populus will be greatful and steadily grow. Do things poorly and your city will clear out faster than a zombie apocalypse could make it happen. Numerous tools are at your disposal as expected with an interesting dynamic that truly brings the realism into the game. Cities can be carved up into different districts and each district can have its own set of policies and characteristics. Players even choose the names. But it doesn't just stop there. Players can give custom names to just about everything in the game including its citizens. Transportation and pollution will be key challenges as with any game of this type. Having experience with previous endeavors like the Cities in Motion series, Colossal Order has easily found a way to challenge players along these lines. Cars and trains, ships and planes. Cities Skylines has it all. The water simulation is spectacular as well. Placing your sewage disposal upstream, for example, could result in contaminating your citizens' water supply. Realistic flooding is another possible scenario. The maps included are gigantic and beautifully designed terrains that offer endless possibilites when planning your city and continued population growth unlocks the ability to expand to adjacent tiles on the map as well as making more buildings and options available (such as taking out loans). These options are tied in with overall success and not just simply from having enough funds available, a feature which definitely enhances the experience.I could go on and on about all of the things I admire about this game. The graphics are solid but not overly done which allows for most systems to be able to run this game smoothly. The UI is easy to use and understand. The "Chirper" social media feature is a clever modern touch that keeps mayors abreast of public opinion and concerns. And, perhaps one of this game's best features is the inclusion of asset and map editting tools to allow the Steam Community to heavily mod this game in order to continue its growth and stability in the future while adding tons of extra content and replay value. In fact, about the only area I found lacking in this game is not having a variety of random events such as natural disasters. I cannot say with certainty why the developers chose not to include them and perhaps they will be added later as DLC since most Paradox Interactive games are known to offer quality additional content long after initial releases. The modding community could possibly offer them as well, since I predict the Steam Workshop will quickly fill up with a large variety of added content. Fires, floods, pollution, infrastructure and transportation issues are still more than enough to keep players challenged and fully engaged though, so overall its not really a major concern.The Good:+ Solid graphics and rich detail.+ Realistic simulation elements.+ Challenging gameplay with various difficulty settings.+ Variety of buildings.+ Many customization options.+ Easy-to-use UI.+ Extremely high replay value.+ Mod-friendly with editting tools included.+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements.+ Pleasant audio/background music.The Bad:+ Lack of random events/natural disasters.+ Graphics could be more life-like.+ Terrain cannot be changed during actual gameplay.Final Thoughts:Cities Skylines is the best City Building simulation developed in a long time and quite possibly the best ever. Expect this game to continue to grow in popularity and become the new industry standard for games of this type. An amazing game with well-designed features integrated into it for such a small development team and a limited budget. Its definitely worth the price and I highly recommend this game to all fans of simulated strategy/cty building games.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												I've played 10 hours and I have seen everything the game has to offer.There's next to no challenge is this game, once you get your city of the ground. After that, it is chugging out more zones for the city to grow.People complaining about not enough healthcare? Dump another hospital somewhere in the vicinity and the issue is solved. Once your city is going money is no longer an issue.This cycle repeats until you are too bored to continue.The only interesting and difficult part is managing your traffic, which is somewhat annoying since you need to reach a certain population milestone before you can start building highways and such, making it hard to plan your infrastructure in advance.There's also this amazing feature of the game (or maybe Unity) eating up as much RAM it can get its hands on. My system has 6GB of RAM and Cities: Skylines decided it should use 4GB of that storing god knows what. Chrome even had to move all of my tabs to the pagefile to make room for the game.This game is fun, but only for a short bit. Don't pay much more than a tenner for this game.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												This game is advertised as a 'challenging simulation' so I bought it with expectations to get a city planner/builder with depth, challenge and realism. All I got was a shallow sandbox game. You can spice up the difficulty with a hard mode and mods, which basically results in having less money and income thus having to wait longer to be able to buy the stuff needed to progress.Yet there is nothing that can make up for the lack of more complex game mechanics. The game offers an over the top local traffic simulation which is far from believable and some minor challenges which are easily overcome by building appropriate infrastructure at the right spots.There are indeed a few mechanics where policies and economy matter, but nothing to write home about. In general the game feels incomplete and oversimplified.+ If you like sandbox games with good mod support and simply enjoy building beautiful cities you will probably also like this. - If you're a fan of simulations and believable game worlds you will be highly disappointed. Not worth your time and money. Gets boring quickly and lacks replay value.

number of helpful: 60 of 117 people (51%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												This game is good as a City builder sandbox. But will fail to captivate Simcity 4 fans. Why?Because he management part is simple! There is no real challenge to the game thanks to a progression system and the inability to experiment.All these flaws rears it's head 5 hours into the game. Visual and performance-wise it's fine, nothing to really complain about, the workshop would solve the generic art direction. There are few good ideas here and there,  like how far a service can be reached is shown by street instead of the usual circle. There are some other good ideas which seem incomplete or not having a prominent, noticable effect - e.g.: Day and Night budgets.But the game focuses on macro-management rather than micromanagement. Pro: it's less overwhelming for those looking for a sandbox experience.Con : it's too limited for challenges in maintaining a city.  Examples would be how taxation is done, how zones are handled, how structures are available.  All of these have a formula to them, without anything disrupting the formula. The game overall becomes a formula.  No Natural disasters. Fires are harmless and only burns down the building without spreading. The problem solving? Formula!Decision has a consequence, consequence has a solution, 99% it ends there No rinse repeat. Therefore the game just doesn't throw challenges.The progression system is the big deal breaker here. It allows you to play safe without experimentation. In order to get buildings you need to cross a certain amount of population. In my first city I happened to unlock buildings conveniently as I could afford them and sustain them. For some reason it's easy to  earn more money than you spend. There is alot of bad UI decisions, one notable one - the annoying twitter bird, that sits inconvieniently on top-center of the screen. The game is also missing a way to control day and night cycle, however I realized that that would break the game budget mechanic (which allows you to set budget for services based on time - Again a good idea which is very underdeveloped).It's here when the mirror begins to crack. The games popularity and critical acclaim comes from all the anger and spite towards EA's Simcity 5, which I though was such an awful game that people consider mediocre titles like "Cities Skylines" as the resurrection of the city building genre which we've been desiring since Cities XL. Yes, that game we would be playing if it wasn't for the crappy engine. Bottom-line, C:S is good as a sandbox for your young one or casual relaxing city building experience. It's bench-marked with SImcity 5, a game which can make a - square drawn in MS paint and exported as a jpeg then renamed to a .exe - look better.Planning takes a backseat here, sadly that part was never advertised. Because this was always advertised as "A deserved sequel to Simcity 4". This game seems unfinished and the gameplay is very underdeveloped.

number of helpful: 24 of 46 people (52%) found this review helpful98 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												You can stalk your own citizens! I followed a guy named Mark (I forgot his last name). I was for sure Mark was a terrorist. He looked like a terrorist, smelled like a terrorist, and even talked like a terrorist, or so I imagined. He had just gotten off of his boat as a tourist.All his other tourist friends took the subway, but not Mark. Mark took his car... Fishy right? I followed him in his green van. I knew something was up. Who drives a green van? Mark does. He got onto my freeway and this is where I knew it would go down. Traffic was backed up for miles. What did Mark do? He waited, just sat there. His plan was failing, and I knew it. All of the sudden he merged into the left lane. Oh no! His plan was back into action.He later turned into my industrial area. Well played Mark, you though I would be stupid enough to think you worked in industry. Well guess what MARK! I know you were a tourist! You don't work in MY city! He couldn't shake me, and he knew it.He continued on with his plans to terrorize my city! There he drove back onto the freeway. Trying to cover his tracks I see... He merged left. Then left again. He turned... right into my tourist area. How suspicious I thought. He only wanted me to think that he was a tourist in my city. I wouldn't fall for it. He parked his green van on the right side of my road, only this road was no parking! Mark had slipped up. I knew he was up to something as he got out and went to go "sight see." I would NOT fall for that Mark. Not this time.Hours passed, days it seemed, and yet he was still sight seeing in my tourist district. I had to think of something before he carried on with his plan. It was too late. Mark got back into his car... I knew this would be it as he turned on his blinker politely and merged back onto my freeway. He was going to blow up my bridge... I saw it in his eyes, eyes that deceived everyone. Those crystal blue eyes hid a dark secret that I had yet to find out.The sweat ran down my face as Mark crossed my bridge. It was safe. But he was heading back to the tourist ships, there he would surely make his move. He didn't... He left my city. Until we meet again Mark. I'm onto you.9/11 ......Mark

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6
												Citites: Skylines is both more forgiving and more in-depth than the likes of SimCity 4. Running out of money is a lot tougher, and there's a lot more to manage like the size of your roads, sewage, and cemetaries. The game starts off really slow as, unline in SimCity where unlocks are based on the year, the unlocks here are based on population, so you start off with coal power and no high-density zoning. Over time, the game opens up, and you get a lot of room to build and experiment. If you like city builders, this game is definitely a solid 9/10, it shines in comparison to the likes of the newer and even the classic SimCities.

content:
Posted: March 7
												Cities: Skylines is the new gold standard for city builder simulation games, and will be for the foreseeable future (probably until Cities: Skylines 2 in 5-10 years if Paradox can think of ways to develop a sequel that improves on the original). If you were a SimCity fan disappointed by Maxis' last SimCity (2013) but still like the genre, don't hesistate, C:S is the new standard bearer. If you're price sensitive, wait for it to go on sale, and it'll be a great deal you can sink hours into.Pluses:+Active mod community+Ongoing development with value-add expansions and DLCsMinuses:-No multiplayer, e.g. the regional maps in SimCity 2013

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2016
												Rating - 7/10Probably the best citybuilder since the big name in the industry missed the mark in 2013.First, the good:Decent visuals Large city areaGREAT mod support Reasonably deep simulationTools to create maps, assets, and themes already in base gameThen, the bad:Agent-based pathfinding (garbage truck conga lines, unrealistic travel of water and power, emergency vehicles sent from a random station instead of one immediately next to the building that needs help)Small tracklist of repetitive musicLack of challenge past a certain point in most citiesWonky traffic AI (no right turns on red, no way to assign turn lanes, cars occasionally get stuck)Overall, I enjoy Cities: Skylines.  I certainly recommend it if you enjoyed Maxis' excellent city sim series back in the day.  It's definitely not without flaws, but the modders have helped with most of the issues I have with the game.  Besides, they're a small team of passionate people who released a game that in many ways surpasses what a AAA game developer put out just two years before.  I'd call that a huge success story.Final rating: 7/10:  If you like the genre, this is a must-play.  If you don't care for citybuilders, this may change your mind, but wait for a sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												This is my first review I've written, so here it goes.I've played Cities Skylines for 350+ hours so far, including the After Dark DLC, and I can truly say that I am addicted to this game. Ever since it came out on March 10th, I barely have time to play any other game that I've bought because I just can't get enough of it. I downloaded Steam primarily to play this game after playing SimCity 2013 for two years prior.I can honestly say that this game makes up for the mistakes SimCity 2013 made. Cities Skylines contains bigger cities, cims have a home and job which they actually travel to (instead of randomly parking at the nearest home or building), creating your own maps in the map editor, and workshop support which modders have posted some outstanding work on. I could list even more pros but I would be rambling on forever. The other thing I like is that the devs at Colossal Order are actually listening to the community, replying to users questions and concerns, and are working their absolute hardest to satisfy everyone, and if they can't do something, the modders are always willing to give it a try.Now the game is not perfect. It can get laggy (at least for me) sometimes but that's really minor and I can deal with that. I'd like to see some weather changes added to the game but I am in no hurry to see huge updates as the game has surpassed my expectations. I'd like to have the population limit of 1 million increased although, I completely understand why the devs put it in. Although, I thought I saw that in the last update that several limitations were increased, though I can't be sure if the population limit has changed. Other than that, I have no real complaints or concerns at this point and I fully recommend Cities Skylines. If I had to give it a rating, I'd give it 9 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												It's hard to say anything more about this game that hasn't already been said by hundreds of people before me. So I will just put this into my own perspective. I really, really, really like this game.I have been playing city simulators since the first SimCity was released. The genre has come a long way since those early games. I have played pretty much every SimCity (including spinoff games such as SimCopter) excpet for simCity 2013, lets be honest it's not the greatest entry in the series, and modern takes like Cities XL. So right away I felt at home with Cities: Skylines. What I really like about this game is it's deceiving simplicity. To start with the game is easy enough to get even new players to the genre building with ease. And for veteran players the interface all looks similar enough to what we have been using to settle in very quickly. The city population milestones means new services and enhanced buildings are brought in steadily. However it soon becomes more challenging to manage larger cities as the populous need more attention to keep happy. But that challenge never seems over the top or unfair. It is managable but you have to be on your toes. I would really reccomend this game to anyone familiar with or new to this genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												Cities: Skylines is an amazing city builder. I haven't playes a Sim city game in a long time, admittedly, but Cities: Skylines really brings the genre to the forefront.The logic to this game is very good, where every peice of traffic or people actually has something to do, rather than just being cosmetic. This does make things a bit trickier, but overall that is much more fun. Similarly, the mechanics of district zoning is something I hadn't expected, but turns out to be really useful.Things do tend to get a bit hectic when you end up with a large population [>100,000], but that may just be due to my own lack of experience.The audio graphical design to this game are really good. It makes it a joy to just sink in to playing for hours. From a wide angle view of the environment, right down to the models of buildings and vehicles it all looks and sounds great. The interface isn't overly complex or cluttered, and it is easy to learn. The modding community to this game is amazing as well, with loads of great content. The devs are even taking hints from various popular mods and integrating relevant additions into the game itself, which is always nice to see. That, and the few gripes I do have about the game [like no tree brushes] can easily be fixed by a mod. They install easily, and I haven't had any game breakages from them.This game is definitely worth buyng if you like city builders, or simulator games of any kind.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												I'm going to edit my review since I don't think my previous one was that good.In Cities: Skylines, you can build cities. It's pretty realistic: you have to deal with traffic issues and what not, you have to build fire stations so your buildings don't burn down, you have to build cemeteries and crematoriums, etc.Overall, the game is very good, but what makes it even better is the Steam Workshop support. Without mods, I wouldn't have gotten the 67 hours I have logged on it as of time of writing. There's mods for basically everything. You can install mods so you'll have lots more of building varieties, you can add landmarks to your city, you can have a gigantic statue of a hamster if you want, there's mods to change the color of your roads or even Americanize them if you want.. As of recently, you can even mod VEHICLES: I can now see DeLoreans driving my city.And you can install a mod... with one click. You don't need any dragging & dropping folders, etc. like for other games like GTA IV.The developers are very great as well. They listen to their community and they are very active.This game was very well worth it in my opinion.

												It reminds me of the old Simcity from Maxis they did ages ago. But its more modernized with todays standard city building game needs. Just awesome. One small mistake can ruin your city in no time. For example, I gave my city sewage water to drink because it wasn't far enough from my drain pipes...so they all eventually died...just great :).This game will remain on my computer for ages... I recommend itPros: Beautiful graphics Simple to use but can become complex and hard at some point Steam Workshop for mods Looks simple but with some time, you'll know its more complex...so its not you're basic Simcity 1 game Fired Maxis employee's play this game but won't tell you Developer and publisher house are small and can do better than Maxis and EA Lots of replayabilityCons: Lack of sim communication feedback (think of simcity4 sims on the streets giving feedback) Learning curve UI needs work a bit Not needed,  but lack of end game for goalsLast thing to note is the number of things gets unlocked. I find this unusual as its more of a skinner box technique so It's not a really bad thing but the more you get your population growing, the more things it unlocked so you can use them. So I can't really put it in pros or cons in my opinion.Highly recommended game to buy if you liked Simcity or City XL type of city building game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
												Pretty amazing game overall. There's a lot of depth in the gameplay and after playing, you quickly realize how complex traffic can be when your city starts to grow. One of my favorite aspects is the data provided for evaluating the effectiveness and outreach of your hospitals, schools etc. That really helps you decide where to focus at any given point. I also like that you can manipulate the roads while paused. It's hilarious to watch what the vehicles do once the game is unpaused. One big thing I think would help is not to close the road panel when you simply just want to deselect the type you currently have. That part is frustrating as I find it a common occurance. I also think some of the camera controls could be bound to the mouse as it's a bit frustrating to manipulate otherwise. The game is very demanding, so if you're playing on an compatible laptop, expect it to run very hot (without third party cooling help). It's a very addictive and fun game and I feel it presents a lot of real world design challenges and can make you really appreciate many city planners, techical and skilled worker's jobs. I highly recommend it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												Cities: Skylines is what the latest Sim City should have been.  A complete city simulation but be warned of the expansions as they do not yeild enough content to warrant the price!   Cities: Skylines in a brief description is a city simulation in which your ultimate goal is to design a city that meets your requirements.  There is no actual objective, no missions, just a pure sandbox play.  You start with a tiny town and slowly grow into a spawling city.  As you level up your city through population milestones you unlock more necessities of a large city.  Proper planning goes a long way when it comes to city and even town design.  You can quickly have a large traffic jam for miles if you don't engineer your roads correctly.  Even if you create a 6 lane highway to bypass traffic, the rules in this game will insist the that inhabitants of the area take the shortest route not the quickest route.  This must be considered when designing the road systems from the very beginning.  It is all too easy to get caught up in building out blocks and areas for your industry and commerce and totally forget about the road requirements.  An easy way to start off is to build a road then delete it, this opens up other roads that are not initally available for some reason.  As you progress you can make freeways, underground roads and suspended roads for more efficient travel.  It takes a civil engineer to make a good road system and I obviously need much to learn in this department despite my advances in understanding how to properly build a road system.  As you grow you zone your areas much like Sim City.  You have your basic residential and commercial and then as you grow you can get into the high density residential (skyscrapers) and high density commercial as well as office space.  Offices provide commerical output and don't generate noise like a typical commerical zone would.  Think an office versus a diner or gas station.  Day and night, rain and fog, as well as snow if you have the expansion are all weather effects.  The day and night were free additions to the game but the expansion for the nights adds other buildings as well.  You can adjust budgets per time of the day.  If you want, you can increase budget during the day hours and decrease the budget for the night hours since they have two independent sliders.  What I find interesting, is that school is also in session at night as well as a few other services that normally wouldn't run during that time.  Elementary at 2 am? Sure thing, get your♥♥♥♥♥to school.  There are mods out there and tons of add-on buildings that people have created using the asset and map editor.  There are so many mods that you could easily fill up a quarter of your harddrive if you went nuts about it.As I continue playing Cities: Ckylines, I find myself always coming back and wanting just 5 more minutes.  Sometimes I'll expand into a brand new district I have planned out and end up wanting to quit in 5 minutes but end up playing another 45.  This game can really take some time out of the day if you let it.  You can design a small town with sewage spilling into the river or expand enough to get water treatment plants and build dams.  If you don't want skyscrapers you can implement policies that limit how big the buildings can get, it is completely up to you.  For what it's worth, I haven't had this great of a time with a city simulation in quite some time.  Since the last Maxis Sim City now that I come to think of it.  With mods, you can easily fix some of the annoying problems like the traffic issue that I explained earlier in that they don't care if the highway is a parking lot, they would rather sit thre than take the new 6 lane bypass you built.  A few other things can get annoying too such as education and the industrial area not building to demographics.  It would have also been nice to deny education to certain schools for a more granular control process but there may also be a mod for that issue as well.A bunch of small issues that don't really get in the way of the big picture.  Build whatever you want, make it look awesome or turn it into North Korea.  Ultimately it is your choice and with a load of maps both official and custom, you won't get bored!

content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
												At first I was like "What's all this hype about? This looks like another SimCity game. Does the citybuilding crowd just get really hype about citybuilders for some reason?Turns out, it's just because the game is fantastic. The city building is great, and you can tweak even the smallest things like policy management and building zones, but the coolest thing, by far, is viewing the individual lives of each of your citizens. They all have their own jobs, houses, and families, and that's just absolutely awesome. It actually makes you feel like a mayor protecting their citizens. It's not about "Get firetrucks to get the burning buildings to stop flashing.", you're actually trying to protect these people (from themselves, admittedly).In any case, I've had a ton of fun so far. I can see myself playing for many more hours to come.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												A quality city-builder though not as Messianic as some make it out to be.Graphcis are solid, but not stunning. Mechanics are a harmonious blend of detailed and easy-to-use.TL;DR below.This game borrows from previous city-builders which had success, namely SimCiy 4 and Cities in Motion, while avoiding the pitfalls which made Cities XL and Simcity 5 disasters.In the end, this game's appeal is greatly heightened by the disappointments of Simcity 5 and Cities XL and it's "Sequels" which looked frightening like clones of their predecessors.While innovative and clever (especially with way pollution directly impacts the game environment via the soil and the water), Cities:Skylines innovates only mildly while maintaining an overall pleasant experience. The graphical experience does come off a bit fuzzy despite settings being maxed and the game is sorely in need of an update which establishes a day/night cycle. A solid game with excellent gameplay. Easy to grasp, semi-tough to master, this game is as solid 8/10 with the potential to become a 9 - 9.5 with a high definitions texture upgrade and a few feature upgrades (smog effects, clouds, weather, day/night cycle to name a few.)While it scratches an itch long unscratched given that SimCity 4 is 10 years old and there have been no legitimate challengers to it's dominance save a disappointing Cities XL experience, Cities is a good that could be great but seems to be a few steps away from being genuinely terrific. TL;DR8 / 10 with the Potential to be better with a few solid updates that will (hopefully) not end up as cash grab DLCs.A good buy at $20 or less, but unless you are desperately in need for a city-builder, I wouldn't pay full price for it.Fun, easy to get into and enjoyable, though a bit fuzzy graphically and asking for an HD upgrade.

Posted: September 12, 2015
												I don't know how they did it but it's incredible, it FEELS like a real city with real people populating the city who need real jobs and real places to go shopping.There are some caveats, roads and planning is hard when you get really big scale. There's a reason there's a science behind city planning and as someone who hasn't been educated in that subject I feel like I might benefit from it from this game.It's really easy to make a town (and very fun) but it's super hard to make a city that doesn't implode.This is not just a successor to Sim City, it's going beyond that. Sim City wishes it was City Skylines!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												Excellent game.It's obvious that the game is automatically to be compared with Simcity game series, and it's not about saying that the one's good and another's bad, but Cities: Skylines really has what it lacked in Simcity.My main points:— The controlls are great;— The cunstruction system is very convenient and easy;— I really loved the zoning;— All the in-game atmosphere: city-growing, the traffic (traffic jams, parked cars, public transport management), the presentation of influence of adding different constructions near the zones — all that looks really vivid and lively, so it's a big pleasure to play the game;The game's absolutely lovely and great, and I'm glad that someone is making quality products like this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												This is probably the best city simulator I have ever played.I was weary of getting this since the last city simulator to come out, Sim City, was a total disaster. But I saw this and everyone saying how good it was so I gave it a shot. It was the best $30 I have ever spent. Well worth it.Some of the features I love are how you can rename not only the buildings, but the people themselves. If you have a problem with saving money, you can either fix that in the economy panel or you can turn off a building. The people rarely complain about taxes up until about 15%, which is lovely as well. Some problems with the game that I have are the traffic (which can be fixed with mods I assume) and theres no weather system yet, which I hope Colossal Order and Paradox can bring in the future. Otherwise, do buy this game. You will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												I want to say its like Sim City 5, but its not. For a couple reasons, The game was playable on Launch Day, There were fixes for the minor hiccups,There was no DRM outside Steam.Cities: skylines City specilization feature works, The population reacts as it should with the actions you choose The ai traffic obeys its own ruleYou arent limited to only one square, but you can aquire more land.The Road building is a little wonky, but it works.   I could go on, It has one small fault, the buildings dont have modules that can be attached to them like in sim city 5. While a fault im sure it can be added to the game, By Devs or by Community Modders. Theres another good side, The devs of this game support moders and it has Steam workshop on day one. If you want a city builder game, look no further.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
Cities Skylines is a good but not incredibly deep game. There is nothing wrong with the game, but you should know that after only a couple hours you will have unlocked everything there is to do. I am still recommending the game, but I hope that they improve the amount ofdepth in teh future. Take for example teh police system. If your crime rate is high, installinga police headquarters willl imeddiately fix it. You do not even have to design routes for the policemen or anything, they atomatically and quickly drastically lower the crime rate. Much of the game is like this; simply building buildings that will lower a certain thing. Pros  The game is fun, and easily addictive. I stayed up very late building that last city block. The game runs well. My computer is not super good, but can still run the game at around 30 FPS. Traffic is designed very well. Cars will react realistically at insterctions for the most part, and will take alternate               routes once you make them Power systems are realict, and you have to make sure to run power lines to the houses.  [There is a large varierty of roads and monuments that can help flavor your city. Cons   Many social systems are only placing a building and that is it. These are the education, fire fighting, police, and healthcare systems. All you do is place a building and the computer does teh rest. That is no fun, and I wish we had more control. Many of teh buildings look exactly the same. They are all generic models only defferentiated by their name. This makes your city look like something in Russia, as opposed to where people actually want to live.  The bird at the top that displays your tweets is incredibly annoying. The tweets are always teh same, and tell you nothimg important. You can disable it and I would recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
ImpressionsFrom the first 2 hours I can already comment the complexity of the simulation in this game is outstanding and runs really smooth, you don't get bogged down; The in game hints offer just what you need. Seems well optimised and has no game-breaking issues that I've stumbled upon yet. From a developer that created transport simulations before; This game holds nothing back. You WILL get traffic problems if you don't plan ahead and it's your job to fix it or problems arise in game. Things progressively get difficult as you expand into new building grids. The map size is huge for those who are worried. With a quick mod you can unlock the full map allowing you to build huge metropolis's. The game is so detailed you even rename pigs...  After spending over 4 hours in the asset/mod manager alone just perfecting and learning the way roads form, with their one way systems or complex intersections and then to finally implement them and watch the traffic flow freely made me smile. Repeating on many reviews; This is the game SimCity should have been. With the built in map editor you can recreate your home town/city and see how the game stacks up against the real thing. With, already, hundreds of workshop items from the community ranging from; custom maps, buildings, highways, junctions and items you wont run out of ideas or playable maps any time soon. With fluid camera motions and a in-game "Tilt Shift" filter, there are some amazing screenshots around already.SummaryI really want to review more but I'd end up writing an essay. All in all I highly recommend this game for anyone, from casual to die hard city building fans. Both groups will find their niche.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												I don't write reviews often but this game definetly deserves it. After the fiasco that was the last SimCity, I've searched long and hard for a modern city building game that could satiate my desire to be the mayor of a giant metropolis.The freedom you have to create your city and exand across the map are tremendous. You can create your own cloverfield intersection with the road tools if you like, or plop down the prebuilt ingame one. There are also loads of mods in the workshop that add all sorts of neat ingame content.Perhaps the only forseeable downside to the game is the fact that there are no disasters. As a person who played simcity with disasters disabled, however, I don't see that to be a problem, and the developers have stated they will add it in the future. Overall, this game deserves the price tag and it more than beats Maxis' SimCity. If you're on the fence, watch a few videos and decide for yourself!

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												On release day, I started playing when I got off work and before I realized it, it was midnight and I hadn't eaten dinner. I was so physically weak from lack of food I could barely get out of my chair. 10/10 would be malnourished again.The game plays and feels like the city builders of the late '90s and early 2000s. As far as I've been able to tell, the city building genre died after SimCity 4. I've tried playing the XL series, SimCity Societies and 2013, and at best they feel dead and soulless; at worst they're broken, boring and a waste of time and money. This one feels fresh while relying on the classic mechanics, and ends up being the most fun I've had playing a city game since 2003. This is the game I've wanted for over a decade but haven't been able to find.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												This is the game I wanted SimCity 4 to be.  It has tons of flexibility with the transport network, and it's easy to build curved roads, elevated railways, and so on.  It's very easy to build any type of city - well-planned, organic, chaotic.  Fill it with smokestacks or Japanese Gardens!The game uses tile-based zoning for R/C/I.  It also has a "districting" feature that helps name neighbourhoods and set special rules for different parts of town, which is a nice touch.Zonable land is indicated next to access streets, and since it still has to be broken into squares for the game engine, it gets a bit wonky on hills, curves, and acute intersections.City infrastructure buildings are oddly sized compared to the 8x8 street grid size.  I can understand a University or Garbage Dump being gigantic, but something like a high school or hospital should be more reasonable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												Cities: Skylines is, in lack of a better description, a super Sim City. Even in the game's community the inhabitants are referred to as "cims" (instead of "sims").When creating and growing cities, at first the challenge is about budgeting but soon the biggest challenge is about functionality - whether creating new neighbourhoods intelligently or micro-managing the ones that already exist. The ammount of micro-managing, especially traffic, is inversely proportional to the thought you put into creating new neighbourhoods.The game fools you into thinking "hey, this is easy, i keep an eye on demands and create what they need and the city grows" but then, when you notice, you have sick citizens because of pollution, burned down buildings because the fireman can't reach the fires, traffic jams that don't allow people to go to work or, even if they do, don't allow cargo trucks to keep the economy working, etc.One thing is for sure, after some hours playing this game, you will think about your own town's city planning whenever you go out and drive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												IN SHORT: The game is great, no glitches (that I've ran into or noticed), mod community is amazing, and the simulation is perfect. This is what SimCity (2013) should've been. If you were disappointed (like myself) about SimCity (2013), you should give this game a try. I've played it about 12 hours since buying it 4 days ago, and it's addicting. Good game!FULL REVIEW: I've been into city simulation games since SimCity 4, and when EA announced SimCity (2013) I was extremely excited. It looked amazing. However, upon getting the game it was a huge waste. Random disasters was annoying so I ended up playing sandbox all the time. Offline mode didn't come for months. The city sizes were small, everything was just terrible! I ended up playing at least 7 hours before I was done.Few years later, I'm checking Keralis' channel when I see his Cities: Skylines series. I'm like, "looks like another SimCity, no thanks." Watching a few episodes, I find myself EXTREMELY impressed. This is what SimCity should've been. Exactly.After checking this game through, I ended up buying it, for HALF the price of what SimCity costed, this seemed worth it.12.5 hours of gameplay later, I'm still enjoying this game. At first, it seems like you have as much space as in SimCity... THEN you unlock more areas, and it gets bigger and bigger. My city is at least 3x the size of a SimCity city. I was also impressed with the graphics. I'm running a pretty terrible computer right now, and using medium graphics works well. Plus I liked being able to change the keybinds, something you couldn't do in SimCity.Oh, did I mention highways? Yep, that is what sold me. The amount of customization in this game is incredible. Ramps up, elevated highway across the city, curved ramp along the shoreline, pretty much everything is possible with the road controls.Only things I did not like was the one way street direction controls, which was easily fixed with a mod; the cars' pathfinding, which I've somewhat understood, just hate how they don't use multiple lanes when going the same direction; and curving roads can get a bit difficult, especially in tight spaces where the road is trying to snap to other objects. Otherwise, everything else is good.I HIGHLY recommend this game, many hours of fun for me and many hours to come! Can't wait to see what I can do next.

												I have been playing Sim games since Sim City 1.  I can finally stop buying City builder games!!!!  This is the best I have ever seen.  If I went into all that this game has to offer this would turn into a novel.  The top highlights I have seen so far is as follows:The road layout - there are no limitations. The most detailed incredible view of a city I have ever seen. Zoom out to see it all.No limitation on spreading out.  Normally with city builders you’re locked into a small square to build in. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2015
A modern city builder that will suck your time if you're into that sort of thing.You start with a road, this connects everything in your city. You then zone the sides of this road to allow people and businesses to move in. They need power and water like any modern city, and then they can grow. Of course, then you need education, policing, fire coverage, rubbish collection, healthcare... and this is before you expand beyond your starter tile, unless you want some interesting times which is also good.You can tweak your taxes and expenditure, have different taxation between different districts of your city and ban lorries from going through your residential area. Or just ban pets if you despise cuddly things.Create new land, flood that new land and bulldoze houses of residents who backtalk you on Chirper while flooding their new house if they won't leave.As long as you enjoy games about creation and don't mind a slow pace of things at times(or ridiculously fast when you suddenly run out of poo capacity), I honestly think as long as you meet the minimum requirements you will have a good experience with this product. Colossal Order have done a massive credit to the genre with this title, and gave it humanity again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												"Everything Sim City should have been" AND MORE!Not only was it perfectly playable on launch day and I have so far only encountered couple of minor glichtes, it sucks you right in. Pros:-lovely art style, good mix of real and toy-like aesthetics -runs very smooth, even with bigger cities-very high attention to detail(e.g. ambulances actually carry sick people out of building, vehicles use turning signals, office workers leave the offices to go for a smoke and many many more) you can spend hours watching your citizen -music and ambient sounds fit perfectly-districts and district specific policiesCons:-personally I feel money is too easy to come by-roads sometimes try to snap really weird-no overview of all public transport lines and no easy way to delete them-some plots look too small, especially for agricultural and forestry industry-you might be sucked in for hours before you realize itConclusion:Considering this game was made by only 13 people and the low release price this game is a must buy for every fan of city builders or similar genres.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Excellent game with a lot of mods and a very strong community. The game itself is very good for being recently released and is constantly getting updates. Here are my ratings:Graphics: 7.5/10 (It is OK but not the best... some mods can make it better)Content: 9.5/10 (Mods make it excellent)Realism: 9.5/10 (Traffic simulation could be better, ie the lane usage)Replayability: 10/10Performance: 6/10 (Extreme lag on cities ≥250,000)Overall, if the performance would be fixed then i would find myself playing the game more. However, I'm capped at playing with a population ≤100,000 people because of performance related issues. Regardless of the performance setting I would choose, the game would fail to surpass 15FPS which deems it unplayable, and I am playing this on a Core i7 2.3Ghz Nvidia GT650M 8GB DDR3 RAM... not impressed.

												I have never played a city builder as good as this one.+ Plenty of road options and things a city needs (fire stations, police stations, etc)+ Workshop support which contains so much (amazing) user-made content+ Each citizen and building has it's own name+ Citizens have little animations, like sitting and playing on a tablet or roaming on a skateboard+ Basically includes Cities In Motion, meaning you control public transport+ Make your own maps and assets, and share them+ Traffic management, even if it is overwhelming and hard for me, it's still fun trying to find methods to organise it+ Creativity within the building of the city and the way you build it+ You can walk around as a citizen/car and look at your beautiful city+ It looks stunningOne negative about this beautiful and absurdly amazing game:- I've found the community is a little hostile at times and if you have had a problem with the game, Reddit is probably the best place to search for an answer.How dare you be so perfect. content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												This is by far the best current city builder. I bought it shortly after it came out because I had been eyeing Sim City (the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 2010(?) release) but didn't like the cut of its jib. I can say this is incredibly fun and satisfying, with active and helpful devs. There are a few minor annoyances, like the AI seems to have stupid pathing on highways (sitting in the middle lane until merging at the last second to get off their exit is a particularly annoying bit). However, this could be due to my faulty city design. The building is great, being able to switch from "snap" mode (great at making hard angles or straight roads) to "fluid" mode, where you can build free-form. Also, building styles are varied enough that your city looks diverse, yet not too diverse that it seems out of place. Overall, this is very fun for the casual city builder or hardcore one. 10/10, highly recommend.

												I have found this game to be very well made, fun to play, engrossing and supported wonderfully by a great community.  As you build your understanding of the mechanics, it becomes more and more interesting.  The developers created a great balance in this game.  Some systems are handled simplistically to speed things along and others require a bit of management.  To build a functioning, growing city takes thought and consideration of a variety of systems issues. To make it also beautiful requires another level of thought, but develops a love and satisfaction within us.  The expandability with the workshop addons and mods from the community along with the asset and map builders make this game something that can be played in many many ways.  I love it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												After the Cities XXL fiasco last month, I had little to no hope that a decent city builder would ever be able to come through. Cities: Skylines proved me wrong. This game is amazing. When you are building your city you have so much to think about to make your city run the best it can. Below are some of my pros and cons for the game.Pros:-Amazing water physiscs (build a dam in a bad place and it floods your city)-Huge map, grows with you (you start the game with a 2 by 2 km sqaure, similar to that of Sim City, as you reach milestones you are able to expand and purchase more squares, up to a total of 9 squares without the mod and with the mod you can purchase up to all 25 squares)-active environment (lots of cars and people moving about)-customization (you can zone off districts, name them, have special policies in each district, and you can even rename vehicles, homes, and people!)-asset editor and map editor (its fun to make your own intersections, buildings, maps, parks, etc.)-powerlines and water pipes(you have to connect power and water to your buildings, makes the city builder 10 times better)Cons:-the snapping of roads gets a little funky sometimes (really hard to make a highway on highway interchange)-the overlay with natural resources cant be opened at the same time as district zoning (if you want to designate a district to be farming, you have to guess where the fertile land natural resource is)-only a one lane off ramp, a one and two lane off ramp would be cool to add more realism-you can't change one way streets to two way streets without deleting them (if i build a curvey neighborhood with a one way street and later decide i want to make it a two way street, i have to demo the whole street and attempt to rebuild, which is almost impossible to repeat the same exact curves used)-I'm having a few bugs with loading in workshop items/maps, but I think they are working on it now (will edit when fixed)Either way don't let those cons stop you, they are little things and I'm sure they will be fixed one way or another. This game is absolutely awesome and I would recommend to anyone, especially with the price of only $29.99.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Fabulous Game!It may seem boring, Building a city. But it is seriously addicitive, Your constantly trying to figure out what you could do to make your city better. The game makes you feel like you want to plan your city out on a piece of paper before you start. I would highly recommend this game, I cant stop playing it!! Tips: 1. Dont put too many junctions in the roads, later in the game it will cause major traffic problem. Major traffic problems means that your residents will struggle with Garbage and Fires as vehicels cant get to them fast enough. 2. Dont build too quickly, I started games off where I built quite a large city with the start off money and ended up in debt. 3. Make sure your constantly saving you game, You can get a Mod from the Workshop that will make your game save every 10 mins or so. Cons: If you play on MAC (like i do) you encounter some graphical issues, hopefully they will get a patch out ASAP.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This game is really a much much better SimCity then SimCity itself. I think the whole genre should be renamed after this game.My wishes for the future:More maps out of the box coming with the gameUnique landmark buildings like a special historical residence that actually works as a residence. They should add a whole lot of variety to your citiesMore focus on the economy and production side of the game. You have a great working city simulator why not extend its capabilities to also include economic simulation in a more detailed fashion.My first complaint about the current state of the game would be monuments. They are way too powerfull ! A building that removes need for any ecucational facility ? I do not agree with that. Instead it should be something that increases the efficiency of the current facilities.My last complaint is about terrain height handling. As with all similar games this one also cannot really handle height differences gracefully. Still this is by far the best game of its kind.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												IN SHORT: The game is great, no glitches (that I've ran into or noticed), mod community is amazing, and the simulation is perfect. This is what SimCity (2013) should've been. If you were disappointed (like myself) about SimCity (2013), you should give this game a try. I've played it about 12 hours since buying it 4 days ago, and it's addicting. Good game!FULL REVIEW: I've been into city simulation games since SimCity 4, and when EA announced SimCity (2013) I was extremely excited. It looked amazing. However, upon getting the game it was a huge waste. Random disasters was annoying so I ended up playing sandbox all the time. Offline mode didn't come for months. The city sizes were small, everything was just terrible! I ended up playing at least 7 hours before I was done.Few years later, I'm checking Keralis' channel when I see his Cities: Skylines series. I'm like, "looks like another SimCity, no thanks." Watching a few episodes, I find myself EXTREMELY impressed. This is what SimCity should've been. Exactly.After checking this game through, I ended up buying it, for HALF the price of what SimCity costed, this seemed worth it.12.5 hours of gameplay later, I'm still enjoying this game. At first, it seems like you have as much space as in SimCity... THEN you unlock more areas, and it gets bigger and bigger. My city is at least 3x the size of a SimCity city. I was also impressed with the graphics. I'm running a pretty terrible computer right now, and using medium graphics works well. Plus I liked being able to change the keybinds, something you couldn't do in SimCity.Oh, did I mention highways? Yep, that is what sold me. The amount of customization in this game is incredible. Ramps up, elevated highway across the city, curved ramp along the shoreline, pretty much everything is possible with the road controls.Only things I did not like was the one way street direction controls, which was easily fixed with a mod; the cars' pathfinding, which I've somewhat understood, just hate how they don't use multiple lanes when going the same direction; and curving roads can get a bit difficult, especially in tight spaces where the road is trying to snap to other objects. Otherwise, everything else is good.I HIGHLY recommend this game, many hours of fun for me and many hours to come! Can't wait to see what I can do next.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												TLDR: The SIMulator of a CITY that won't let you down. Don't let the "Cities" name fool you. This game is indeed another in the Paradox Interactive "Cities" franchise, but it has none of the problems those game had ( poor performance, memory leaks, mediocre graphics sometimes, lots of paid dlc, a game re-release every year).This game, by the folks of Colossal Order is the city simulator you waited for since SimCity 2000.Running on Unity Engine, this game totally delivers a good experience and will sink you a few hundreds of hours, in the pursue of the most-efficient-city.As for the size, your cities will be huge. You start with a 2x2km tile, and by reaching population milestones you'll get the chance to purchase  up more until you have 9 total.Why 9? Because most computers will be able to simulate 9 of them .want more than 9? You can unlock the full map (5x5 tiles = 25 tiles) with SteamWorkshop mods since DAY ONE.+ Solid Gameplay+ Runs smoothly+ Graphically sound.+ Ingame content generation (can import heightmaps to create real world maps!)+ Steam Workshop support+ Modding capability+ The UI is really competent - It didn't come out sooner

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I've been waiting on what SimCity promised but couldn't deliver. This is it. A few things are broken, buildings start abandoning for no reason above a certain population level which makes for a clicking chore where you have to clean up all the greyed out buildings around the map. But the map size is huge which is what made me fall in love with SimCity 2k. Doesn't have as much micromanagement as SimCity but maybe that's a good thing. The traffic congestion can also be a bit tedious to manage but thats to be expected from a game company that produced a traffic management sim (cities in motion) as their last game. All in all it's a great game and depending on what it is I might pick up DLC in the future.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												I'm stunned by this title. Being a loyal decades-long fan of the SimCity franchise (first I've seen it as a SNES game) - Cities Skylines is what we passioned city builders always dreamed of.Detailed, entertaining, making sense - it just all works well and nicely. It is well balanced (i.e. a short water or power don't screw up your rep entierly), makes fun and is really detailed. You can control anything. And stuff like item distribution, resource allocation and traffic - it all makes sense. And if you see a problem and you correct the source, the problem actually goes away! (this was hard with some SimCity's)..If you in *any* way like this genre - pleeeeease buy it and give it a try! You will not be disappointed my friend ;-)

A good game, just like the games Paradox always release :)Good points :- All that everybody says : quite big map, avoidance of Sim CIty and Cities XL mistakes- The traffic management is great, i sometimes spend lots of time just wtching people go arround and optimising stuff- The water physics is great, careful with that :)- Graphics are nice and clear, and even if the game is not as detailed as the last Simcity, this may not be a choice for a big map.- haven't seen a bug after almost 20 hours playingReally nice to play right now, this game still has a few points that may be improved, but I know we can count on Paradox and Cities Skyline teams to make this game even better over time.For now the points that should be improved :- Deleting destroyed buildings manually can be boring in a big city as you have to destroy like 10 buildings all arround the city. A mod prevents this from happening, and allows me to just sit and watch my city without having to pause every 3 minutes to clean up arround :) I know a well organised city has less destructions, but when you reach 50000 hab, it's a lot of work to delete everything^^- The roads. It's great already, but a certain game (that you, Paraddox, should know well :p) named cities in motion 2 goes a little bit further in terms of flexibility. This first thing that would prevent us from destroying all a fully evolved neighborood, would bhe to be able to upgrade a two ways road in a one way road. This would be really great, since it is one of the most frustrating points. The other would be to personnalise the number of ways on a road. For example, if you want a one way road, you can have the small one way road (2 ways) or the one way big road (6 ways). All highways have 3 ways and entrance 1 way (or 3 ways if using a highway). Why not being able to have two ways entrance or a 4 ways highway ?About the roads, I know that since the AI transport algorithms must be really complex (and they are, actually, the best of all city builders) and may be limitating the possible choices.Anyway, I look forward for update and extentions for this game !And if you're looking for a city builder, don't hesitate, this is probably the best one now, and this is made with love by Paradox <3Good luck to the amazing dev team :)
