content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												When I first saw screenshots of the game, I thought: wow, it looks really nice, but will it be any good?The answer became clear to me when I watched youtube videos of it and read other steam reviews. And that answer is yes. I bought the game, and immediately fell in love with it. It truly is the best city builder game since Sim City 4. $30 is a really good price for this game.Here are some pros and cons:Pros: + Easy to learn         + Amazing water physics never before seen in a city builder game         + Make your own maps with ease         + Easy to download and use player created content         + Every single person in your city has their own lives, families, cars, houses, etc.         + You can click on anybody in your city to see where they live, where they work, where they are currently going, and what they are doing, and also follow them around to see what they do.         + Realistic sewege system (watch your sewege pipes pour poo water into the rivers/ponds/oceans, and watch it spread around in the water)          + Realistic traffic system (cars drive way more realistic than in sim city, and they don't disappear when they get to their destination, they park and the owner gets out)         + You can rename any building, person, or animal in your city, and also rename your districts.         + You can make districts         + You can build water pipes and power lines like in the good old sim city games         + Detail everywhere (See ambulances go to houses and pick up patients with a stretcher, hearses picking up dead bodies, garbage trucks picking up garbage, delivery trucks taking goods to shops, etc)         + Beautiful graphics         + Runs really smooth, even with everything set to Ultra with my Gtx 560 ti 2gb, I get 40+ fps in huge cities, and 60+ fps in small cities.         + You can import real locations into the game by importing heightmaps you can download on terrain party, and use them in-game to build cities on.        + I still haven't noticed any bugs in the game        + Detailed transportation system (make bus routes, train routes, metro routes, etc.)        + Lots of different road types to choose from, and lots of things you can do with them.         And now for the cons, most of them can be fixed by downloading mods from the workshop though.          Cons: - No day/night cycle (there's a mod to fix that)                   - No weather system or seasons                   - Abandoned buildings can get annoying (But you can prevent abandoned buildings if you are a very skilled city builder, or download the mod that auto-destroys them) And that is all. Yes, that is seriously the only problems I have with this game, otherwise it is the perfect city builder.                                                               9.7 out of 10

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												The best city builder in years!  With the most recent Sim City being a giant flop, and Cities XXL feeling very much like a repeat of Cities XL, I'm glad Cities Skylines came about.  The cities can be absolutely massive, the level of detail is very exciting, and there are many features new to city builders!  They could use a few more industry specializations  (Having oil, mineral, farming and forestry already) including perhaps some which we saw in the failed Sim City (Gambling for example), and improved tourism, but its a massive hit so far.  There are always ways to expand though and the fact this game offers so many ways to mod it (for both relatively weak custom content creators like myself, and pros) and that the unique content can be easily shared through steam workshops makes it never ending fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												Cities: Skylines is the best city building game that I have played to date. Unlike any other that I have seen, the focus of Skylines is not on fine budget management, or clever zoning, but on traffic management. After your city gets on its feet and people start pouring in, you will spend the rest of the game designing elegant solutions to the gridlock that will plague your city- and slapdash fixes when that doesn't work. Money is rarely a problem, unless you screw up something major and leave everyone without power, or water, or over-educate all your cities and run out of workers, but this rarely happens. Every single citizen in your city has a home, and a job, and they need to be able to get from one to the other easily- no mean feat. When imports and exports are thrown into the mix, snarling traffic jams and clogged up roads  further than the eye can see are inevitable.TL;DR This is one of my favourite games, it's definitely worth the full price of 30USD and is good for endless fun. I'm definitely putting a lot more hours into it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2015
												This game is currently the best city builder around.  If you have ever enjoyed a SimCity game, then I would highly recommend picking this up.  It's insanely moddable, and the maps are huge, especially if you mod out the default size limit.  Just a word of warning though -- if your computer is very old or underpowered, you may have trouble coping with a city with over 100,000 residents, especially if your game is heavily modded.  My computer just about hits the recommended settings, so it struggles a bit with my 130,000 population city if I run any other program at all in the background.As with any city builder, there isn't much to do once you unlock all of the buildings and do most of what you set out to do, but it's extremely addicting to keep growing your city and managing the inevitable problems that a massive city comes with.EDIT: I have a new rig and this game runs very, very smoothly now, 100+ FPS.  It's apparently very processor-intensive, so keep that in mind if you have a very old processor.  My old computer had a 2.93 GHz quad core i-7, and it could just about handle it.  If you have something beefier than that and a decent GPU, you should have no problem.  Anything less and you might run into trouble.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												So freakin' addictive. It's like the days of Simcity 3 all over again.Building plans and road layouts have to make sense, traffic is very realistic and will build up and drive to and from destinations. Have to create special roadways for heavy cargo to make traffic flow like a beating heart. I've never been a mayor but how you play this game, really makes sense in how you would actually run a village/town/city in real life. 50% of my citizens have a college degree, and they DO NOT want to be underemployed lol I found this out after I noticed my population started to drastically decline when I got to about 24,000 people. But you will have to find a good balance, not eveyone is going to want to college, so you will need good high paying highschool education or lower jobs. It's satisfying to find out why a zoned area is having a problem and then turn it into a bright part of the community. Interestingly enough, it's a very simple concept. Treat people like human beings and they will work hard, have ambitions, and in return give the city more money in the form of taxes to help improve said city. Every citizen is going to want to feel safe, have a local hospital staffed by local people close by with honest doctors, not worry about their house family and belongings being burnt up in a fire, Keeping their houses tidy by keeping garbage out of the streets. For instance, the laws have a invest now-risk/reward later effect. Sign a law that encourages people to recycle to help produce less garbage which will keep your garbage dumps clean while you wait to get approval to build garbage powerplants to burn the excess garbage. You'll get slightly less tax income, but you won't have to spend as much as quickly mantaining more and more garbage dumps. I love this game. I wish there were more extreme policies that could only be approved if you met certain conditions like for example- cime is 8%, I can now unlock an outreach program policy that would further reduce crime. I LOVE that they made a policy just to "legalize it", I signed that bill as soon as I could, and then turned around and banned ciggerettes. In my mind, I do not trust cigarettes because of the extra chemicals they include with tobacco, so I wasn't actually banning smoking tobacco, just big corporate ciggerettes; my citizens, seemed to approve, health in general went up 5% and oddly enough so did happiness. It did dip 2% for a few weeks, then rose about 5%. For a small gain of 3% I hope they continue to make dlc for this game, it has so MUCH potential and it's already my city management game of choice as of this review.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												The single best city-builder I've ever played. Cities:Skylines is overwhelmingly fun, addictive, and simply a wonderful experience.Pros:-Great graphics, very detailed-Huge map (without even unlocking all 25 tiles)-Incredible city depth and design-Forming roads and interchanges is incredibly fun (I spent hours fooling around with the various road tools)-Traffic. Oh, traffic. It's very welcome and fleshed out beyond anything I quite expected. Managing traffic is challenging. But in the best way possible.-City data, heat maps, graphs, etc... for your city are presented in a manner that makes them very easy to understand and evaluate. The art and colorful visuals are absolutely off the charts.-Districts are fun and add a different dimension to the game.-ModdableCons:-N/ASo yea, get it. I could sit here all day naming off the positives. But it's worth much more than the $30 price tag.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												Everything I'd hope for and more with a City Builder! The price for what you get is amazing, and I wouldn't have minded paying more.  The modding API, allows a multiude of mods, especially considering the game is built off of Unity.  Just as Bethesda games become amazing by offering a strong game and platform through which modders elevate teh game, so are modders elevating Cities Skylines to horizons not thought possible when first released! And that was only in March! The first DLC has amazing new features, the core of which are free thought additions for full package cost, but at an acceptable price point.  There is no pressure to buy a thousand transactions and the game isn't artificially gated making it seem cheap but with hidden expenses.  It rewards different types of play styles and doesn't pressure you to recruit friends or hit goals counter to your playstyle. Definately a fantastic game.  I look forward to continued work, both by the devs and modding community!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												This is a great game. Not brilliant, just great. 7.5/10. If i had a rosette i'd award it to the devs under the "damn good effort" category in the games awards ceremony that plays in my head :).It lacks the depth of the Simcity series (ignoring the latest one from EA which fails on so many levels) and that is the sole reason i don't keep engaging with the game. Which is annoying, because i want a fantastic city builder :).With the lack of depth comes a lack of difficulty. As other reviewers have mentioned, once you get over the initial cash flow issues you can't spend the money fast enough. Having said that, what that does do is free up your ability to bulldoze and rebuild/redesign.This leads me onto one of the things that i love about this game - the build system. I've read some reviews about this game being all about building roads and that's unfair, but you will be focussed on building road systems to make your city work. But hey, find me a city where that's not a key feature. That's kinda the point isn't it unless you can do away with roads, cars etc with alternative systems but that's not achievable here. You have to have roads, albeit alongside a decent public transportation system etcetc.And guess what, building roads i actually found to be a lot of fun! The devs have done a LOT of work on making roads work for you - you know, when you need to make something connect from A to B but the game can't "figure out" the connection - 99 times out of 100 this game does it right, even if it does natively lack a few road junction layouts which would be useful. Combine with this limitless funds (once you've got yourself up and running with high density) and you can trash and rebuild as much as you like within reason. This allowed me to explore different possibilities to see what worked which i found difficult in Simcity due to cost. Maybe that's just me.Yes there are some issues with the game - lack of depth (compared to SC4, come on we have to compare to SC4, it's unavoidable :); lack of variety in buildings etc; forgiving pollution; no real advancement in how water supply works (basic build a supply, connect with pipes - i'd rather it was just removed as it adds nothing imo etcetc but hey, it's a pretty good city builder.If anything, the popularity of this title demonstrates how much people really really want a deep city builder/management game. Given what we have received with this game I'd say this dev team are the ones to do it!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
												This is a great game. Not brilliant, just great. 7.5/10. If i had a rosette i'd award it to the devs under the "damn good effort" category in the games awards ceremony that plays in my head :).It lacks the depth of the Simcity series (ignoring the latest one from EA which fails on so many levels) and that is the sole reason i don't keep engaging with the game. Which is annoying, because i want a fantastic city builder :).With the lack of depth comes a lack of difficulty. As other reviewers have mentioned, once you get over the initial cash flow issues you can't spend the money fast enough. Having said that, what that does do is free up your ability to bulldoze and rebuild/redesign.This leads me onto one of the things that i love about this game - the build system. I've read some reviews about this game being all about building roads and that's unfair, but you will be focussed on building road systems to make your city work. But hey, find me a city where that's not a key feature. That's kinda the point isn't it unless you can do away with roads, cars etc with alternative systems but that's not achievable here. You have to have roads, albeit alongside a decent public transportation system etcetc.And guess what, building roads i actually found to be a lot of fun! The devs have done a LOT of work on making roads work for you - you know, when you need to make something connect from A to B but the game can't "figure out" the connection - 99 times out of 100 this game does it right, even if it does natively lack a few road junction layouts which would be useful. Combine with this limitless funds (once you've got yourself up and running with high density) and you can trash and rebuild as much as you like within reason. This allowed me to explore different possibilities to see what worked which i found difficult in Simcity due to cost. Maybe that's just me.Yes there are some issues with the game - lack of depth (compared to SC4, come on we have to compare to SC4, it's unavoidable :); lack of variety in buildings etc; forgiving pollution; no real advancement in how water supply works (basic build a supply, connect with pipes - i'd rather it was just removed as it adds nothing imo etcetc but hey, it's a pretty good city builder.If anything, the popularity of this title demonstrates how much people really really want a deep city builder/management game. Given what we have received with this game I'd say this dev team are the ones to do it!!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I have enjoyed playing management/city building/strategy games since they first start appearing in the early 1980's and recently I was asked to start reviewing mods for Cities: Skylines on a couple of websites.Why Cities:Skylines, well it has an amazing modding community that has transformed an above average city building game into an amazing one. The majority of these coders are quiet and unassuming and simply brillant, while a few others are worse than Kanye West (arrogant, self righteous with their heads stuck up their own a backsides) and only so-so coders that blame their short-comings on others. But all-in-all it has a great community that is always coming up with new ideas for making this game more realistic and fun.City building doesn't get much better than this. The modding community has already made this game so much better and CO are still adding new features.If you are a die-hard city-builder or a novice, this game is a must. Great game as it is now, The definitive city-builder game in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												After seeing a friend play this, I bought it and while being similar to Sim City 5, this game is far superior, cheaper, and supports mods! I paid $60 for Shim Chitty vs $30 for Cities, a bargain in my book. Anyway, I started a new game and decided to go with a green small suburban town to get used to the game. I loved the road tool in Shim Chitty and Cities took it a step further (+1). My only complaint is the lack of a uniform grid when free forming roads in the middle of an area. Cities definitely has quite a bit of road selection to choose from and the road upgrade tool is a life saver (This game has one way roads too! +1) Next up, I went with a main avenue and zoned commercial along it with developments and windy back roads for residential (Standard setup I assume). When I unlocked parks further on, I built pedestrian paths through the middle of residential areas and bridges over main avenues to allow for shortcuts and because I felt like it made those blurry little people happier (I base my cities around the concept of improving the quality of life). I'm only at 3,000 population at the moment because I'm taking my time and enjoying the game. That's it so far.The best thing is I don't have to worry about space because I can buy adjacent plots of land.... Man what a concept... Genius...So all in all, yes, it's almost the same as Shim Chitty. Pros: Save/load game, no Origin, lots of development space, road types for all ages, water pipes, little blurry people, buildings can spawn in nearly any sized zoned lot, and ORDINANCES (I love ordinances, when Shim Chitty took them from me a piece of me died). That's all I can think of at the moment, like I said its Shim Chitty, but 10x better.Cons: Lack of public buildings (IE: Libraries, museums, and park types) and Pet ban ordinance (Seriously?)I may have missed things as I've only played 4 hours so far, but I'm loving this game already. EA/Maxis/Origin, I hate all of you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Following on from their excellent transportation manager games Cities in Motion 1 and 2, Cities: Skylines makes the leap to a full city builder that was the obvious next step after Cities in Motion 2.  Obvious that step may have been, but that doesn't make Skylines any less good a game.  Cities: Skylines is the definitive city builder of the modern era.  If you remember the SimCity games fondly then you will enjoy this game.  Certainly it blows the Cities XL series, which is probably the closest equivalent, out of the water.That said, the game is not perfect.  The traffic path finding can be a bit off at times - people forcing their way through the city centre rather than taking an orbital highway for example.  In the vanilla game at least your citizens have a fixed life span, if you zone large residential areas in a short space of time this leads to 'death-waves' that can easily swamp your deathcare capacity.  Large cities with a lot of mods running will run slowly, especially on older machines, but that is inevitable given the level of detail in the simulation.On the other hand there is a very active modding community.  There is already a mod that introduces probabilistic deaths that can ease the 'death-wave' effect.  The developers are also active and developing new content.Overall if you like city builders, buy this game.  If you think you might like city builders, then this game might well convince you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Long ago, 13th of March, I wrote a negative review about this game. Now I feel it's time for a re-review, since the game has seen some updates and expansions, as well as some mods.I would like to start writing about what is incredibly good about this game. A few things stand out, like the water physics in this game, which is very impressive and fun to play with. Another thing that I really enjoy is constructing roads and trying to solve congestions. It can be surprising how a small adjustment downtown can solve giant traffic congestions that affect the whole city. Visually the game has improved, mostly thanks to third party mods though, like 'Dynamic Resolution', that enables  'SSAA', which in short just improved anti-aliasing a lot, and 'Ambient Occlussion'. These are hardware intensive additions however, but I don't understand why these options aren't available in the default graphics menu.Other mods have also vastly improved the game, such as the Terraform Tool and the Traffic Manager. The modding community is definitely a strength which potential influence I greatly underestimated.What I still find underwhelming, however, is the economic simulation, the pattern at which buildings are erected and the transition from small town to metropolis.The industries actually work with a production chain from raw resources, that you can either harvest yourself, or automatically import into the city, to feed manufacturing plants (industry without raw resource designation), to exports. One issue is that this system is not even really obvious. It's something you discover if you pay attention, while it should be a core gameplay element in my opinion, that the whole city should be all about. Importing resources should cost more money, while harvesting them should cause more pollution, or something along those lines.The skyline in Cities Skylines tends to top off around a certain height. Eventually whole city quarters are filled with 30-story buildings, making it look really uninteresting. Why do all buildings max out to the same level? Maybe they should insert a mechanism that the more a building has leveled up, the more negative effects it spreads around it, making sure you can never get a topped off skyline, as the neighbors, under their shadow, will never rise to the same level. Then to raise a neighborhood you would need to provide even more services, but then again a few buildings will rise even taller, while others only rise a little, creating a visually much more dynamic skyline. Also the neighborhood policy to prevent highrises still allows pretty tall buildings in my opinion, defeating the point of it.The transition from small town to metropolis is way too rapid in this game. I was developing a small town, which is challenging and pleasing at the same time. Money is actually a factor and every building matters. Then, very suddenly, it all changes. Suddenly the money just comes in like water, disabling it as a game element altogether, and the whole town starts to look like a miniature New York; with a population of only 30,000. Traffic starts to replace money as the main gameplay element here, which is fine, but more something for a city of 300,000 than 30,000.So I have put down my criticism again, although I didn't mention waterpipes and other silly micromanagement yet, but I look forward to future expansions and mods that have a really positive influence on the game. I do wish that eventually the whole game will be as impressive as the water physics system, but for the current pricetag of under 30 euro, with sales putting it even lower, this is a fine game to pick up, especially if you are into this genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												Cities Skylines ReviewOne of the best city-builder games I've ever played.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Gameplay                                                                                   -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Gameplay in Cities Skylines gives you plenty of options and customization in the game. There are lots of buildings and models, the traffic simulation is detailed and mesmerizing, the zoning, taxing, and budgeting panels are easy to learn, the simulation is deep and visual, and the fluid dynamics put a cherry on top.9/10----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Modding----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Modding in Cities Skylines is extremely simple, easy to learn, detailed, and fun. You can edit buildings, make new ones, make your own maps, and import height maps to create real world terrain maps. The Cities Skylines workshop also has hundreds of mods that you can add in to the game with one click.10/10---------------------------------------------------------------------------------Disasters---------------------------------------------------------------------------------Disasters are the only let down of Cities Skylines. There are only occasional fires that don't even spread, and the only 'disaster' you can create is when you a dam on a fast flowing river and break it to make a devastating wave. Other than that, when it comes to disasters, Cities Skylines is bone dry.4/10--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Developer Involvement--------------------------------------------------------------------------------The devs of Cities Skylines are wide open to suggestion and feedback on the game, they give good feedback to community creations, and they are all ears on social media.10/10-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Music-------------------------------------------------------------------------------The soundtrack in Cities Skylines is beautiful, it's not overwhelming, and it adds a nice feel to the game that makes you feel like you really are building a city.9/10-------------------------------------------------------------------------------FINAL SCORE FOR CITIES SKYLINES:84/100Very good game, I'd recommend it to any city builder fan.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												Hey you! Ever wanted a game that is better then Sim City and is addicting? Do you also want to download mods by clicking a simple button? Then this game is for you! Anyways, jokes aside, this game is honestly AMAZING. Its a lot better then that sh!t Sim City, and alot more addicting. This game is really great, and I would seriously recommend this awesome game to you.Onto the Cons and Pros.Pros:After Dark; After Dark is a DLC, but the day and night cycle is free. Once you expand and make your city huge, the night will make it shine more, and make it more beautiful. Highly Addicting; This game is seriously addicting, you will have 10+ hours on this game, trust me.Highly Fun; This game is seriously fun. The mods keeps the game going, and mods also make it even way more fun.Challenging; This game is challenging, with traffic, and demands, this game will make you keep on playing non-stop. Highly Detailed; If you buy this game, I highly recommend you get the first person mod. If you download this, and go in first person, you will see that the civs are highly detailed. With them holding tablets, phones, having watches, and much more. The devs really did put a lot of care and love into this game.Cons:Intel Not Supported; I have a Intel i5 and this game lags alot for me. I read some forums, and apperantly this game doesnt support Intel's. You can still play it, but good luck.Glitches; Sometimes, this game glitches. Like for example, you have 10 incinerators, but your city still says you need to build more. Sometimes the garbage trucks doesn't even go to the building that needs a garbage truck.Conclusion:So, in conclusion, this game is highly fun and addicting, but sometimes glitches. We'll have to wait until they fix the glitches. Anyways, I highly recommend this game to you, and your friends. You will have alot of fun building your city, and will play non-stop. Thank you for reading, and keep building, Mayor!Like this review? Why not check out my other reviews? And why not thumbs up this review? Thanks for reading, and have a wonderful day.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												The single best city-builder I've ever played. Cities:Skylines is overwhelmingly fun, addictive, and simply a wonderful experience.Pros:-Great graphics, very detailed-Huge map (without even unlocking all 25 tiles)-Incredible city depth and design-Forming roads and interchanges is incredibly fun (I spent hours fooling around with the various road tools)-Traffic. Oh, traffic. It's very welcome and fleshed out beyond anything I quite expected. Managing traffic is challenging. But in the best way possible.-City data, heat maps, graphs, etc... for your city are presented in a manner that makes them very easy to understand and evaluate. The art and colorful visuals are absolutely off the charts.-Districts are fun and add a different dimension to the game.-ModdableCons:-N/ASo yea, get it. I could sit here all day naming off the positives. But it's worth much more than the $30 price tag.

												If you like sim city 4 you will love this game. It reminds me a lot of the rush hour expansion as traffic is your main challenege in the game. Or at least it is for me. It's fun to puzzle out the different ways to make your traffic flow in order to keep your city afloat. There is a lot to do in the game already, but the developers will be releasing free content upgrades which has me excited and given that this is paradox as a publisher I hope to see lots of continued support for this game. I mean crusader kings 2 is how old now, and they are still pumping out expansions for it?This group seems to have the same goal and I am excited.This game has modding support out of the box and already the workshop is filling with people's content, so it's longevity is assured. At 30 bucks this game is a bargain, grab it, snag it, play the heck out of it if you love city building games.I would give this game two thumbs up if steam let me click that button twice.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												Pluses to why you should get the game:---No forced online only modeBig citiesPlanned content expansionsResponsive dev team from Steam and Reddit feedbackDay 1 Mod supportCloud SavesThere really hasn't been a game like this in yearsWe all got our hopes up and crushed from SimCity 2013, hoping for basically SimCity 2000+4 with better graphics. After that rehashed released of Cities XXL, Banished seemed to be the only 'city builder' game worth playing. I've already put close to 100 hours into Banished and wanted something more on a meta level. Well Cities: Skylines is it!!!I want to try out mods but I'm not sure if it will prevent achievements from popping.Other things I enjoy are how smooth the game runs (tested on 8core 4ghz, 16gb ram, ssd, gtx780). Cities XXL and even Banished ran at low frames after awhile, this game does not.I don't like the fact it doesn't have auto saves, that's really my only complaint. Last night, I spent 2 hours on my town and for some reason stopped getting oil for my power plant which caused the city to lose all money and most of the population. I guess I should have been saving but figured it was assumed based on other city builders.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Before I start the review, let me point out first that this game has a 96% recommendation ratio. So let that sink in for now.So, Cities: Skylines, or as I like to call it: How SimCity Should Have Been.It's really easy to draw comparisons to the EA IP, so let's do that real quick: This game does virtually everything that SimCity does, but better.It has somewhat the same mechanics but with a more user friendly touch to it. Skylines is overall just that, really user friendly. You'll find the learningcurve to be not steep at all. Once you get the hang of it in the first hour, you'll quickly start building your metropol.The difficulty of the game is set by your own creativity. Thats a shame because there is no real challange. If you want to build crazy shapes of roads or an unconventional city all together, youll find that there is de bottleneck. There are no disasters, and even if you mess up your finances or the entire structure of the city, the game will still be very forgiving. Besides that one downside on this game, there isn't anything to add to it. It's flawless in gameplay, there is a huge variety of third party content with the steam workshop implemented. And finally, the game is really addictive. There are plenty of things to unlock. From unique buildings to special types of roads. The game really has a nice pasing in that sence. Also, it looks amazing.So, without any real negative sides to this game, let me just say 'wow'. Buy it already!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												I have tried so many city builders before.  The last few years I have been disappointed by a lot of them - Sim City, Cities XL, etc.  However, Cities:  Skylines has blown me away.  It's not as "pretty" when compared to other games, but it doesn't have to be.  It truely feels like a simulated city.  The biggest thing I noticed in this game is how the flow of traffic affects your city, which I think is a great thing.  It doesn't feel random.  Each car has a place to be and it makes sense the route they take, which you have to plan around.  Plus, the cities are huge, but it gives you time to open up a new section in your city so you can develop what you currently have.The only downside is the build variety isn't there.  However, that is such a minor point.  This game is worth $50, but they only charge $30.  So it's defiinately worth a buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
ImpressionsFrom the first 2 hours I can already comment the complexity of the simulation in this game is outstanding and runs really smooth, you don't get bogged down; The in game hints offer just what you need. Seems well optimised and has no game-breaking issues that I've stumbled upon yet. From a developer that created transport simulations before; This game holds nothing back. You WILL get traffic problems if you don't plan ahead and it's your job to fix it or problems arise in game. Things progressively get difficult as you expand into new building grids. The map size is huge for those who are worried. With a quick mod you can unlock the full map allowing you to build huge metropolis's. The game is so detailed you even rename pigs...  After spending over 4 hours in the asset/mod manager alone just perfecting and learning the way roads form, with their one way systems or complex intersections and then to finally implement them and watch the traffic flow freely made me smile. Repeating on many reviews; This is the game SimCity should have been. With the built in map editor you can recreate your home town/city and see how the game stacks up against the real thing. With, already, hundreds of workshop items from the community ranging from; custom maps, buildings, highways, junctions and items you wont run out of ideas or playable maps any time soon. With fluid camera motions and a in-game "Tilt Shift" filter, there are some amazing screenshots around already.SummaryI really want to review more but I'd end up writing an essay. All in all I highly recommend this game for anyone, from casual to die hard city building fans. Both groups will find their niche.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Cities: Skylines is what the city building genre needed. After the huge dissapointment that was SimCity, I thought we'd have to play SimCity 4 forever (that's not a bad thing mind). Thankfully Paradox has funded this wonderful game. Once you hit 20,000+ pop, it's no longer a struggle to make money to further expand your fledgling city. It becomes a traffic simulator. You'll spend more time re-doing and updating roads once the colossal amount of cars, trucks, vans and bikes swarm your infrastructure. This isn't bad however, it's really fun and I'd like to see all City Building games with it in.The graphics are very nice, although the options are limited and Tilt Shift can get annoying. The sounds are pretty generic, nothing special about them but also nothing terrible. The chirper is annoying though, even though it highlights stuff that's wrong with your city. It gets extra annoying if you legalise drugs. "I iz gonna lite a spliff init"There's not much of an end game, but there usually isn't with city builders. The only thing stopping you is how limited your ambition is. Workshop is very VERY good, there are some must need mods such as automatic bulldoze for example.In conclusion, if you're itching for a city builder then I'd suggest you pick up this game. You won't regret it. If you're new to city builders, then this is a great game to start with as it is relatively easy (barring traffic problems later in the game) so pick it up if it looks interesting to you.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
												Cities: Skylines does a great job of taking the fundamental ideas that Sim City 4 attempted and addressing every issue that the community had with it. The resulting game is something that has the same look and feel of its elder genre brethren but has many of the features the community wanted in it. That doesn't necessarily make it the game that Sim City should aspire to be, indeed Skylines lacks any real originality or direction to where it might be going in the future. It's a solid title, one that plays a heck of a lot better than Sim City 4 did, however it's derivative and the onus is on the community to take it in new and strange directions to help differentiate it from its main competitor. That being said it's still enjoyable to play and most certainly worth its current asking price.Read my full review here: http://www.therefinedgeek.com.au/index.php/2015/03/20/cities-skylines-i-am-a-generous-mayor/

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												10/10In my opinion, this is the PERFECT city building game -- the one I've been waiting for since I first played SimCity2000, oh so many years ago.  This game does what the new SimCity (on Origin) SHOULD have done, and tried (but miserably failed) to do.  For me, Cities: Skylines takes the cake as the best city-builder.Cities: Skylines allows the player to start from nothing, and grow one tiny neighborhood into an ultimately sprawling, fully integrated and interconnected network of high density cities and lower density towns.  You start with one (farily large) square of territory, then build up a nice bustling village, and gradually expand your city by purchasing other, directly-connected squares of territory with new resources and topographic features, until you have a realistic-feeling region.  (This feature contrasts greatly with the new SimCity, which only technically allows you to expand into a "region," since it really only allows you to focus on one square of territory at any one time.  Cities: Skylines gives you a full view of your expanded territory, you can build in any part of your territory at any time, and you can see that your various smaller cities are all a part of a larger interrelated region.)  This ability to gradually expand into a true, interconnected megalopolis, and the additionalability to create smaller districts (neighborhoods), and set policies that are specific to each one, are some of the game's best features.  The game allows you to have real control over what happens in each area of your region.  The road and transportation system is also quite intuitive, and generally allows for easy manipulation and changes.  Transportation systems are easy to set up and change (unlike in SimCity), and I feel like there is a good amount of freedom in setting up roads.  I only wish you could easily change a two-lane road into a one-way road, which it doesn't seem to allow you to do.  But that's a minor critique of an otherwise STELLAR game.  I will say that the game sometimes runs a little choppily on my crappy (but new) Acer laptop, and the graphics are a little fuzzy, but I am positive that this is the result of my aforementioned crappy machine, and not the result of any programming flaws.  Also, the imperfection of the graphics on my machine does not lessen the value of the game for me.  In my opinion, this game satisfies all the requirements for a perfect, ever-engaging city-builder.  The replay value is amazing.  I have put in 45 hours of playtime in about two weeks (by starting and expanding three different cities), and I know I've still  barely scratched the surface.  I can't wait to see how my cities progress!!  If you enjoy the city-building genre, then BUY THIS GAME NOW!!!  Take it from someone who's played just about every city-building game that's been released in the past 25 years - Cities: Skylines will make a worthy addition to your collection.  10/10; 5 Stars; A+++

												There are some games that are completely addicting and force me to play for just another five minutes (which turns into hours). Cities: Skylines is one of those games. This game does what many city builders cannot. It has the feel of the Sim City series with just a few problems:-Traffic (4 and 6 lane roads are not helpful in most cases)-Not enough people per skyscraper building if you want realism. It's incredibly difficult (potentially impossible) to reach millions of people in your city-Not multiplayer and unable to attach your own cities together to create a bigger metropolis with more traffic issues (that was something that Sim City 4 still does well for singleplayer)Still the majority of the game is amazing fun with challenges to unlock important items for moving forward. I have no idea how many cities I have gone through and it still doesn't get old. It's a must have for anyone who enjoys a simulator.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2015
												From loving games such as Sim City and Roller coaster Tycoon I have been looking for a good city management game for some time.  I can spend countless hours reworking roads to improve traffic flow and find laying water pips to be a peaceful experience. If that’s you, you might want to give this game a go. Unlike sim city, which it barrows heavily from there are no disasters. The biggest threat to your citizens will be fire. My few play throws the fire became a pain in how many burnt buildings I had to bulldoze. Though that was partly my fault I got rid of a street connecting the fire house. You could say the game was trying to bring my attention to this by burning the people of my city. City: Skylines is the definition of a city builder simulation game.  Its goal is to give you the tools to create a prosperous city the way you see fit. Through a wonderful mechanic called districts I could regulate an industry heavy district to provide farm goods. Personally I like my cities to be eco-friendly and concentrate on resident happiness instead of trying to make the most profitable city I can. From years of playing these types of games, the fun comes from living the fantasy of running your own city your way. City: Skylines seems to understand this. From their UI and overall look of the game people will compare it to Sim City 2013. Though I think as time goes on people will start to point out how this game sets it self apart. You can only see this through playing it.  It's a warm and welcoming feeling for people that want to dive into a city they can make into their own. This game also comes with a map and assets editor. From little I got to play with this feature I have to say its nice to create your own intersections to use in your maps. It keeps things uniform and saves you time from wasting cash and deleting unnecessary from roads that you have to replace, anyways. The developers have thought of steam workshop integrating from the get go. From seeing games of this type try to integrate other players into your game, like having a multiplayer function I much rather have this type of integration where players can add to each other's cities through making unique props, buildings and intersections. I would recommend this game to anyone that love city management games. It's one of the better ones.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												This is what I (and you) have always wanted to play in terms of a City sim. The good old Sim City 2000/3000 feel is there, and made much better by a variety of enhancements (simple overlays for indicators, area of effect on buildings before you place them, accurate visual cues, etc.). Conceptually, the game is a bliss. Most things are inherently understood by the player or well summarized by their popup explanations. Still, an advanced in-game tutorial for certain things would have been appreciated (albeit you can see the wiki from the main menu). Most importantly, none of the BS from the more recent iteration of Sim City is to be found. Example: instead of paid DLC for nicer looking structures (and feeling as if you were shortchanged with an incomplete game to start with), they come free of charge. And if you ever felt there weren't enough models, you can either make them yourself or find some on the Workshop. It also looks like tons of people like to share their models on Workshop. Despite certain shortcomings (the Tweeter feed isn't always very useful, the soundtrack could be expanded somewhat, rivers and water in general is somewhat lackluster), this game made me believe in the city sim genre once again. Truly worth its "overwhelmingly positive"
